TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I ask him: If the recent surge in imports reflects a rise in imports of capital equipment, why have the expectations for investment in plant and equipment for 1988-89 been revised downwards substantially in the September quarter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, we are seeing an enormous structural transition occurring in the economy, with very strong investment reflecting itself in a very sharp rise over the year in imports. In today's national accounts we have got investment in 1987-88 revised up to a real 13.7 per cent for the year, but still confirmation by the Statistician that the 12 per cent forecast in the Budget will be met; that is, the maintenance of 12 per cent investment off an even larger base than we had expected or understood at Budget time. I might say that both the Prime Minister and I were saying last year that we thought investment would be larger, when the figures were taken with some hindsight, than that which was around in terms of the expectations data. I am happy to say that the numbers do confirm what we were then suggesting-that is, the 13.7 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: So what we are saying is that for the first time really in the postwar years we are not seeing a lift in Australia's commodity prices and its terms of trade squandered by a binge in consumption. We are seeing the fruits of higher commodity prices and better terms of trade invested in our long term future, invested in a change in the productive structure of the Australian economy-unlike the coalition Government that presided over a substantial lift in the terms of trade, coming from a lift in oil prices and coal prices, that was also absolutely squandered in a consumption boom, which then led to a wage blow-out, which then wrecked the economy and gave us the first negative growth in 30 years, in 1982-83.

What we are seeing here is the Australian economy growing solidly-but with the mix of demand heavily concentrated in investment-moderate private consumption, and the expectation that that investment phase will continue along with the strengths in corporate profitability, and that the arms of policy are there, set to maintain that change; that is, fiscal policy as tight as it has been in 35 years, wages policy holding firm, as again confirmed in today's national accounts, and monetary policy playing its proper role in moderating demand. All that means is that Australia is seeing annual growth figures in investment the likes of which it has not seen in the postwar years. That will transform the Australian economy to something like the kind of modern, sophisticated place it should always have been instead of the backwater it became under the Liberal Party and the agrarian rump now called the National Party.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. I understand that last week he released the report on the Singa Sea disaster which occurred in July. Does the report disclose any matters of serious concern in the response of the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre? Is any follow-up action proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think honourable members are aware that it now transpires that on 4 July the Singa Sea, a Filipino flag vessel which departed from Bunbury in Western Australia en route to north-western Europe containing a shipment of copper ore and mineral sands, apparently split in two and sank in the Indian Ocean. Some days after that six survivors were found in a lifeboat in the Indian Ocean. Concern was expressed at that time about the circumstances in which that may have occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: What happened was that the ship sailed from Bunbury on 2 July and the last report received from it was on 3 July. It was on the following day, apparently in heavy seas, that the Singa Sea split in two and sank with the loss, finally, of 19 lives. Let me say, as I have previously, that it is important to express credit to Mr Martus, who was the second officer on that lifeboat and who was able to maintain sufficient discipline among the six survivors to ensure that the flares which were available to them were not wasted in any situation of panic. In fact, that lifeboat drifted in the Indian Ocean for 29 days before the six were sighted by a Greek vessel and brought back to Fremantle and hospitalised before being sent back to Manila.

Some points of concern were raised by the honourable member for Grey. I understand the reason that he raises this question, because he has a real and personal concern about the maritime industry and people engaged in stevedoring and maritime activities. I appreciate the circumstances and the concern that would have prompted the honourable member to raise this question. There were a number of circumstances which in a number of ways were extenuating in regard to the response of the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre. It is important to realise that in the first place the Singa Sea did not notify its departure from Geraldton after it arrived at Geraldton to start picking up its cargo for north-western Europe, nor did it indicate when it arrived in Bunbury. So there was some inconsistency in the way in which the Singa Sea radio operator was responding to the expectations under the Australian ship reporting system of the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre in Canberra.

Also, on 3 July-the day before the vessel sank-there was a significant departure of the Singa Sea from the route that it was following. In fact, that departure, which was in response to advice that it had received that gales were expected, would have placed the vessel about 40 to 50 nautical miles off the route that it was following. That would have seriously prejudiced the opportunity for any search to have been undertaken satisfactorily. It would have placed it at the perimeter of the area in which its position would have been located.

As a result of the inquiries that were undertaken by the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre in Canberra, the ship's agent in Fremantle had suggested the possibility of some inadequacy in the radio operator's ability. Apparently the person who was responsible for that suffered from some inexperience, and there was the possibility of some serious disability and deficiency as far as that was concerned. The Singa Sea ship management in Singapore also said that the ship could have had some transmitter problem. When no report was received from it on 4 July, no immediate search was undertaken then because of those types of extenuating circumstances. I accept that Mr Bob McCullough, the Director of the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre, would have been expected to use his experience and professional judgment to determine whether a search should have been undertaken.

There was also no EPIRB-that is, an emergency position indicating radio beacon-in the lifeboat itself. Had there been one it is very likely that we would have been able to identify its position much earlier. Also the ship that went down was a 26,500-tonne bulk carrier, and it is not usual to lose vessels of that kind. So there were a number of circumstances that resulted in the fact that it was not until 27 July, when the vessel should have arrived in Cape Town, that any significant search was instituted. At that time it finally became clear that the vessel had been lost and when the six survivors were picked up from the lifeboat, they were able to explain the situation. I have asked the Director of the Department of Transport and Communications to undertake an inquiry within the Department to ensure that the procedures which are adopted by the Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre in future are appropriate to circumstances of this type.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Sydney for his question. He and a number of other members in the House have a substantial proportion of aged people within their electorates. As such, they have a very real interest in the approach to retirement income policy. It has been clear to the Government since the beginning of the social security review that this was an area of policy that we would need to look at in some detail. Work commenced early, at the commencement of the Cass review in 1986, on the area of demographic change and the shift in the population that was occurring in Australia and that would continue into the early years of the next century, and the development of a range of options for the Government to consider. The results of that review have been very recently published.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the intention of the Government to ensure that that report is read extraordinarily widely within the Australian community and that consultations occur primarily in the first instance through the Prime Minister's task force in local communities across Australia. I am pleased to say that the first of those consultations took place this week in Queanbeyan and they were quite successful. But consultations will be undertaken at a grassroots level right across Australia. We will need to ensure that consultations occur throughout the welfare sector. I understand that the Australian Council of Social Service and the Australian Pensioners Federation will be involved in those consultations. The Government will also be consulting with relevant sections of the industry.

It is important to recognise that we face certain clear issues. The number of people over 65 in the population is expected to increase from 10.7 per cent in 1987, to 11.7 per cent in 2000 and to 12.6 per cent by 2010. The normal retirement age for men has crept down over the past two decades. In 1986 about 80 per cent of men aged 60 to 64 were still in the work force. By 1987 this had dropped to just under 45 per cent, and that is a massive change. So there are issues of very great substance to be addressed in relation to retirement income policy, particularly in respect of the ageing of the population and the tendency for people to move out of the work force in their fifties and sixties.

In terms of the Government's approach, we are not interested in quick fix solutions. We are not interested in an approach which is simply concerned about any immediate electoral impact. We are concerned about achieving a comprehensive approach. We are concerned to ensure that for the vast majority of age pensioners, three-quarters of whom have incomes of less than $40 a week over and above the pension, the issue of adequacy is addressed as part of the review, at least in the longer term. We are concerned to ensure that over time we have not only a policy which is adequate and which addresses issues of equity, but also a policy which, most of all, is sustainable. I conclude on this point: what has characterised this Government and not the Opposition, either in government or in opposition, is its capacity to deal with issues in the longer term, to deal with serious policy questions that involve putting settings in place.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Howard) proposed:
That so much of Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith the following motion of censure:
This House censures the Prime Minister for misleading Parliament and the Australian people in his answers at Question Time yesterday.
Mr Beazley-The Government will accept the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Prime Minister for misleading Parliament and the Australian people in his answers at Question time yesterday.

This censure motion is not related to questions of friendship between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and people in the Australian business community. This motion is not related to questions of the attitude of people on the Gold Coast towards developers or the attitude of people on the Gold Coast towards people of Jewish background. This has something to do with only one thing, and that is whether this Parliament can believe the word of the Prime Minister. That is what the motion is all about.

It is perfectly obvious that we have seen in Parliament today, culminating in the refusal of the Prime Minister to answer the question of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the putting into effect of what can be called plan B of the Hawke response to the allegations that first appeared in the Sunday Mail only three days ago. Honourable members will remember, and all journalists in the Parliament will remember, that the claim made was that, according to Sir John Egerton, a former member of the Gold Coast City Council, the Prime Minister had telephoned the mayor and had telephoned other members of the Gold Coast City Council making representations on behalf of a Gold Coast developer in relation to a development proposal.

I put aside, for the purposes of this debate, the question of whether there was anything improper in the Prime Minister making those representations at that time. I say neither that it was proper nor that it was improper. I put that aside. I am not saying that it was entirely appropriate and I am not saying that it was not. What I do not put aside is the way in which the Prime Minister behaved. What was perfectly obvious from the moment that that allegation was made was that the Prime Minister, who on many occasions when he is under attack is nothing better than a writ happy bully, set out to intimidate and bully his accusers into silence through threatening to use legal proceedings. The Prime Minister may scoff and those on his front bench may scoff about this, but let us see what he said in Melbourne on 27 November 1988 in answer to a question. I will read the answer from the official transcript issued by the Prime Minister's office:

Let me make this statement clearly and I hope you understand it and all its import. The statements attributed to Mr Egerton and reported in some media last night and today are defamatory and untrue. I have instructed my solicitors to issue proceedings against Mr Egerton and any media which repeats these defamatory statements.
Here is the threat:
So I hope you understand clearly the import of what I'm saying because it has an import for Mr Egerton, the media which has reported his defamatory statements and anyone who does it in the future.

I say to the Prime Minister and to the Parliament that if the Prime Minister's response was as he gave it to us today, why on earth did he not say last Sunday what he said in the Parliament in answer to a question from his Whip? Why on earth did he not say, `Of course I was in Surfers Paradise; so what? Of course I know Mr Kornhauser'? I am not asking him to deny that he knows Mr Kornhauser. I am asking him to tell the Parliament the truth. I am asking the Prime Minister, when he is confronted with a question, to give it an answer and to give it a truthful answer. But no, there was something embarrassing about this claim. There was something about this claim that made the Prime Minister feel a little uneasy and a little uncomfortable. So what did he decide to do? He did not say, `Oh yes, I often saw Eddie Kornhauser on the Gold Coast, we often had people in for drinks, we often talked about world affairs and the weather and I suppose the question of Eddie's development application may have come up but if it did, so what? I did not say anything improper; I did not do anything wrong'. Why on earth did the Prime Minister not say that? Why did he retreat into the coward's castle of threatening to issue writs? Why did he start behaving then and in the Parliament yesterday more like a Gold Coast bouncer than the Prime Minister of this country? Why did he not come clean on that particular occasion?

If anybody imagines that that was the beginning and the end of it, we come to Question Time yesterday. We came first of all to the question from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). When the honourable member for O'Connor asked the Prime Minister, `Will you deny to the Parliament that you made any kind of representations to the Gold Coast City Council in relation to Mr Kornhauser's application?', what did the Prime Minister do? He continued with the bullying tactic. He assumed that the honourable member for O'Connor was referring not, as was subsequently disclosed, to Mrs Diamond's statement, but to the claim made by Jack Egerton. He immediately launched into the same tirade. He used the same legal cloak. He said that proceedings had been issued. He stopped short of using the words `sub judice' but he implied that the issue was sub judice. He allowed the Parliament to draw that inference and now, in Jesuitical fashion, he turns around today and says, `I was not talking about sub judice. Oh, no; you have all got me wrong'. The reality is that he conveyed to this Parliament yesterday the impression that he could not answer any questions and, what is worse, he could not be required to answer any question because he had taken proceedings. That is the impression that he sought to create yesterday. He said:

I repeat: the observation and answer that I gave previously to the honourable member for O'Connor . . . What I am saying is that the issue which has now been raised by Mr Egerton and reported in the media has been repudiated by me and is not a subject of legal proceedings.

So, the whole tenor of the Prime Minister's response yesterday was, firstly, that it was wrong of him to give any answer at all to the question and, more importantly, it was even wrong of anybody on the Opposition side to ask a question.

But then we came to the really critical question that was asked yesterday of the Prime Minister, and that was the question asked by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). This is what the honourable member for McPherson said:
My question is to the Prime Minister and I refer him to his answer to the honourable member for O'Connor. I make the observation that this question has nothing to do with Sir John Egerton.

So, what the honourable member for McPherson was clearly doing was saying, `Prime Minister, this has nothing to do with the matter that you were questioned on by the honourable member for O'Connor. Therefore, it has nothing whatever to do with the matter in relation to which you have taken legal proceedings and therefore you ought to give it an answer'.

Then he went on, and I will read the question because it goes to the very heart of the Opposition's charge that the Prime Minister has deliberately misled this Parliament. That is the charge against the Prime Minister. We say that, in his answer to the honourable member for McPherson, he told an untruth and he misled the Parliament. I will tell honourable members where he told the untruth and where he misled the Parliament. The honourable member for McPherson had this to say:

Is it not a fact that on 16 April 1980 the Prime Minister attended a luncheon comprising Mr Eddie Kornhauser and members of the Gold Coast City Council health and planning committee? Is it not a fact that Mr Kornhauser's Paradise Centre proposal was discussed during the luncheon? Is it not a fact that the Prime Minister told the members of the committee at that luncheon that the Gold Coast City Council should approve Mr Kornhauser's proposal? Is it not a fact that at one stage the Prime Minister said to the Council members that they should `look after Eddie'?

That was the question asked by the honourable member for McPherson, and one does not need to be a genius to work out that that question was based on the signed statement of Mrs Betty Diamond, who was present at the luncheon that the Prime Minister attended. Here is the crucial answer from the Prime Minister. He gets up and says:
I do not accept the statement that has been made. I do not accept the statement put by the honourable member for McPherson.

No doubt, the Prime Minister will say that that does not mean that he was denying it. He will try to tell the Parliament that, when one says that one does not accept something, one is not denying it; rather, one is in some state of neutral suspension between saying yes and saying no.

What in reality the Prime Minister did by giving that answer was to deliberately convey to the Parliament the impression that he was denying the substance of the question asked by the honourable member for McPherson. That is the charge. That is the basis of our allegation that the Prime Minister has been less than truthful with this Parliament. If in fact the Prime Minister did not feel any sense of embarrassment, if in fact there was no problem, if in fact this whole incident did not make the Prime Minister uncomfortable, I would say to the Prime Minister and we would say to the House, `Why on earth did the Prime Minister not say, as he has said today, ``Yes, I was on the Gold Coast. I did attend that luncheon. Something may have come up. I can assure the Parliament that I did nothing wrong or nothing improper and I did not use my not inconsiderable position as President of the ACTU''?'.

However, instead of doing that, what did the Prime Minister do? The Prime Minister sought to hide behind the coward's cloak of having taken legal proceedings. That is what the Prime Minister tried to do on that occasion. Then, having said, `I do not accept the statement put by the honourable member for McPherson', he went on to say:
. . . the observation and answer that I gave previously to the honourable member for O'Connor . . . have no compliance and complete reliance . . .

I do not have the faintest idea what that means. It was a bit of undisciplined Hawkespeak and gobbledegook in reply to a question. But I am bound by the Hansard record and I cannot extrapolate from it. It goes on:
What I am saying is that the issue that is now being raised by Mr Egerton and reported in the media has been repudiated by me and is now a subject of legal proceedings.

The very statement that he had yesterday sought to denigrate, the very allegations yesterday that he said were defamatory and untrue except in relation to one particular, and one particular alone, the Prime Minister admits the whole thrust of everything that was said by Mrs Diamond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

SPEECH.PARA: On Wednesday, 16th April 1980, as a member of the Gold Coast Health and Planning Committee, with other members of the Committee, undertook an on-site inspection of the Paradise Centre, then being built in Surfers Paradise, Gold Coast, by Mr Eddie Kornhauser.

He has since smeared the former honourable member for Port Adelaide, who has now left this Parliament, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). We have had there permanent smears by this Opposition using the forms of the House and, indeed, acting in a cowardly fashion under the protection of privilege and not saying anything outside. Last week the honourable member for O'Connor even suggested that because I happened to make a point against the Opposition about removal of the capital gains tax I was speculating in property. But he never had the courage to say it outside. It is always the coward's attempt, as in 1985 when he was tested on Parliament and he had to lie to the television to abscond from his cowardice. These are the kinds of cowards we on this side of the House have had to deal with in Parliament.

Why is that? It is because there is an attempt to divert attention from policies and substance to personalities and muck, because there is no policy. Today we have had published the national accounts for the quarter and progress in the economy for the year. One pro forma question came from the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock); nothing else. The Opposition was back to the sewer thereafter. It cannot even maintain a Question Time on the national accounts. It has no sense of policy.

We heard that there were to be these policy releases all year. Here is a quote from the ABC radio program AM, from Mr Howard: `I have said all along that the timetable for policy releases by August is going to be adhered to'. He said this in February this year. August is months ago. The same came from the shadow Treasurer when he said, `I think if you contain your enthusiasm you will see the tax policy before the end of the year'. There is no policy, and now we are going to have some manifesto which will have in it intuition, feelings, values and all the rest, from a person who lacks any moral basis for his politics. Serious people in business who support the Liberal Party said to me, `I am so pleased to see John elected as Leader of the Liberal Party. At least there will be some sensible, proper and moral basis to our public life'. I, at the time, welcomed that change. I do not welcome it today, because we have the shabbiest person who has ever led an opposition in this country. He is prepared to denigrate his own country's economic policies by promising unfunded tax cuts in an election campaign-high cynicism for any price. He is prepared to foster racism in this country in relation to the migrant intake and so poison us in the neighbourhood of the world we live in-Asia.

These are the prices he has been prepared to pay for an illegitimate attempt to maintain the leadership of the Liberal Party and to grasp the Prime Ministership. No more desperate, unprincipled individual has ever held the office of Leader of the Opposition than the honourable member for Bennelong. He thinks that smearing us is clever. Making quick remarks under privilege, muttering stuff under his breath at Ministers over here--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I am waiting to see that embarrassed losing grin that I saw on the face of the Leader of the Opposition on election night in 1987. I am hoping to see it, either on election night when it next comes, or before, from a person who does not deserve the confidence of the Australian people, who should never have occupied the leadership of a major party in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, we have a motion of censure of the Prime Minister in relation to his integrity, from a person who has no policy and no policy framework, someone who as Treasurer ran the tax system of this country into disrepute. For three years, the unexplained three years, he turned his back on the advice of the Tax Office and its Commissioner to pursue criminal evasion of tax. For years he let the advice pass, until he was dragged there by the McCabe-Lafranchi report and by the Royal Commission, which his own Government established, into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and which brought him to account for his public policy failure. Do not tell us that it was not because of the whispers around the accountancy profession or business in this country saying, `Do not touch these things'. He understood. He was there to serve those interests. He never touched them until public accountability required him to introduce legislation to deal with them. That is the old slicko stuff we have been treated to by this person.

He talks about dishonesty, about misleading people. Told in the election campaign of 1983 that the deficit would be nearly $10 billion, he walked around for the last week and a half of the campaign letting the rest of the public believe that it would be $6 billion. No national politician has been as culpable of deceit and misleading on this scale as this person. Yet he is here talking about the Prime Minister misleading the Parliament as to whether he is going to sue Jack Egerton or the Courier-Mail, with all of the innuendo, slander and the rest being thrown at him in the meantime. To add insult to injury, we have the motion seconded by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair), the leader of a two-State party-in Queensland and in New South Wales. Its Government in Queensland has been shown to be unambiguously corrupt. The Party to which the Leader of the National Party belongs runs a corrupt government. The Party which he has defended in this House for years, the Ministers he has defended for years, are corrupt. He is now up here talking about the Prime Minister misleading the Parliament, about whether yesterday, in the confusion, he said he would sue Sir John Egerton or the Courier-Mail. It is an attempt to smear. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (MrPeacock), referred to the Prime Minister years ago as `a little crook'. The Leader of the Opposition used that issue against the honourable member for Kooyong to remove him from the leadership. He has picked up the tactic and has kept it ever since. He thought I was unreasonable when I abused him on the telephone in 1986 about his tactics. He ran to the press saying, `Keating's gone mad. He actually abused me for my lack of principle'. I picked you right, brother, right at the turn. I have hounded him ever since. All I want to see is that losing smile glued on his face as I saw it in 1987 and as I will see it again. He may think that he is up here poking muck at us, trying to destroy the reputations of honest people, but we will have our reward when honourable members opposite ponder the next three years of their lives back in opposition, bumping each other in the Opposition corridors, going around of a night to talk to each other to relieve their boredom, watching their lives frittered away day by day, week by week, month by month, year by year. They will then wonder who had the last laugh. They will wonder whether the clever smears of the honourable member for O'Connor under privilege were clever at all, whether taking the Liberal Party to its lowest common denominator did anything for them.

In the suburbs where their seats are strongest such as Wahroonga on the North Shore of Sydney, with the blue rinse sets out burning the leaves on a Sunday afternoon, sweeping up, going in and turning on the television, they see their Party, the honourable member for O'Connor, like the monster from the Deep Lagoon, on the television. Is it any wonder that he is the biggest turn-off ever for traditional Liberals. Yet he has turned his parliamentary Party to the lowest common denominator. He has adopted this posture against a respectable Party of government which produced people such as Barwick, Spender senior, Menzies, Hasluck and people of decency, of principle, of ideas, of intellect and of integrity.

Where are honourable members opposite now? They are with the bar room brawlers, the smearers, and they know it. When the Liberal heartland knows it, we can be sure of one thing and that is that they will stay where they are. Not only will we maintain our vote, pick up our marginal votes and pick up the votes of the decent Australians sitting and watching this contest, but also we will pick up the votes of the heartland Liberals in the marginal seats and the safe Liberal seats.

This low tactic of the Leader of the Opposition to smear and to employ people such as the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for McPherson to attack people under parliamentary privilege will not pay dividends at the ballot box. The electors know what it means for the security of everyone if the Liberals try to mortgage the country, to cause the basis for civil strife, and to poison us in Asia. The electors will reject them out of hand, as they should. This tactic of no principles and no policies, will lead to no prospects. It is those no prospects which will hurt honourable members opposite hardest. They will wonder about the Wilson Tuckeys of this world and the veracity of the cheap jibe and the smear as they ponder those years, their broken lives in opposition, their broken careers and their broken opportunities. They may laugh and sneer, jeer and interject but they will be doing it from the uncomfortable station of the Opposition front bench.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I thank the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for opening up this debate in the way that he has. It is of great interest to me that if we ever needed evidence of the Treasurer's contempt for his lame duck leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), we have just heard it. The Treasurer felt constrained not to defend his Prime Minister or address the censure motion of the Opposition. He felt it was immediately necessary to alter the motion so that he could make a speech that said everything but a word of defence for his Prime Minister. We know that nothing has changed-Paul still wants Bob's job.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not remarkable that he chose that particular defence? What a case of the pot calling the kettle black. After all, who is the person recorded in Hansard as referring to other honourable members of this House as `dogs returning to their vomit'? Who referred to those other honourable members of the House, some of whom are referred to in this motion, as `harlots'? How was he stopped? He was stopped by being given a bit of his own medicine. He squealed. He squealed out on the steps of Parliament and he squealed to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). He showed, as he showed yesterday, that when it comes to being treated by his own rules, he has no heart.

Now that he has opened up the debate in this way, we might talk a little more about yesterday when someone referred to his preselection. There is another coward's castle for politicians and it is called defamation actions. We can all threaten people with that. Every time someone stands up and says, `Hey, we think something is going wrong in Western Australia Incorporated; hey, we think the people are losing their money' we find the Western Australian Labor Party-Dowding, Burke and Parker-out with writs. They slap writs on them. They are stop writs-writs to stop the talk. Look how much it has cost the people of Western Australia and Australia. They are denied the parliamentary process. The Labor Government goes about its business with stop writs and legal action. Its hide is thick in certain circumstances but pretty thin in other ways. The reality is that the Prime Minister came in here yesterday. He was embarrassed because he was associated with a person--

TALK.START.PARA: —The scum of the Liberal Party.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, you would name him if you wanted to prove a few things. That was an outrageous remark.
—Order! The honourable member for Calare will cease interjecting. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.
—If someone from our side had addressed a comment to the galleries in that fashion, one might wonder how they might have been treated.
—Order! One will not wonder that. One will get on with the matter before the House.

—Yesterday we saw a very embarrassed Prime Minister. He was embarrassed because articles in the newspapers had referred to his association with Mr Kornhauser. This was the situation yesterday and even more so on the weekend. The press reports have of course been referred to. It is of interest because it is not that long ago that the Prime Minister came into this place with his pecuniary interest statement to the Parliament. He said the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The public-the electors of this country-are entitled to have confidence in the integrity of their elected representatives; to know that Ministers of the Government will perform their duties without fear or favour; to be reassured that a Minister's private interests-whatever they may be-do not conflict with his or her public duties in holding the high office of a Minister in the Federal Government. With those beliefs in mind the Australian Labor Party has long held the view that public disclosure of the private interests of Ministers-and others, to whom I shall refer later-is appropriate.

That is a pretty high sounding phrase. It is a pity it was not remembered by the Prime Minister yesterday. Yesterday he was still of the belief that nobody had anything on him and that he could bluff his way out of this. My question was put to give him the opportunity to come clean. But he stuck to his guns and bluffed his way through, which is one of the three great statements of the Labor Party. The point I have to make is that yesterday we were talking about Egerton and Kornhauser; today we are talking about Fitzgerald and the Sunday Mail. Why did the Prime Minister not say that on Sunday when he went rushing off, on that day of rest, to his solicitors to get a stop writ in place? One might wonder why, at that stage, he was going to sue John Egerton. Because that is what he said to the newspapers. Let us remember that the newspapers did not contact him; he contacted them. He told them what he had done and warned them of the dire consequences of any of them getting out of line.

We go back to his statement again-`the public, the electors'. So we are not only charging the Prime Minister with misleading this Parliament. Admittedly the rules there are a bit tougher in the short term than misleading the people. The people in the end get fed up with being misled, being told the economy is on the up when their hip pocket tells them it is on the way down. They are getting fed up with the economic treatises of a Treasurer, who has, of course, neither academic nor practical considerations for the task, and proves it day after day in this place when we set before him questions of some technical detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were from the university of hard knocks, Wilson.
—I got out at the right time, and I did not take nine years to get an economics degree, as did our mate Dawkins.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look for a minute at page 654 of Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice-`Deliberately misleading the House':
The House may treat the making of a deliberately misleading statement as a contempt-
I underline that word-a `contempt' of the Parliament-
In 1963 the House of Commons resolved that in making a personal statement which contained words which he later admitted not to be true, a former Member had been guilty of a grave contempt.
That particular case was the Profumo case.

Mr Profumo had sought the opportunity of making a personal statement to the House of Commons to deny the truth of allegations currently being made against him. Later he was forced to admit that in making his personal statement of denial to the House, he had deliberately misled the House. As a consequence of his actions, he resigned from the House which subsequently agreed to a resolution declaring him guilty of a grave contempt.

I do not know whether there is a great deal of difference between denying the fact that one was running round with a prostitute and denying the fact that one was involved with trying to influence the Gold Coast City Council. But if one denies it in this place, one is guilty of a contempt. Yesterday the Prime Minister denied it. Today he has come in--

TALK.START.PARA: —Denied what?
—Yesterday the Prime Minister quite clearly denied that he knew anything about the meeting put to him by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White)--
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.
—I would not hire either of the gentlemen opposite as lawyers in my defence if they were able to have a--
—Order! The Minister for the Arts and Territories will cease interjecting.
—I wouldn't have let you go in the first place, Wilson.
—Order! I warn the Minister for the Arts and Territories.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your protection. The point is that in this case the Prime Minister clearly set out yesterday to deceive the Parliament. Today he is going to rely on the mumbo jumbo of the words. It will be up to the media and others, hopefully, to look very closely at what he said in the Parliament yesterday and make their own judgments on behalf of their readers, because they too pay for the newspapers and are entitled to the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, yesterday, it was a case of Egerton and Kornhauser. Suddenly that has got nothing to do with it; it has got something to do with the headline and the fact that Mr Fitzgerald's photograph is included. In answer to his own Whip's question, specifically designed to avoid the confrontation that the Opposition then had to force upon the Prime Minister by way of this resolution, which otherwise would have been dealt with had he made a statement in the proper course, he tried, even there, to avoid having to answer properly to the Parliament.

The reality is that the Prime Minister changed the rules today and has admitted that he did attend the meeting. He is now requiring people to believe that he did not say the things that Mrs Diamond so clearly remembers. I guess Mrs Diamond would remember the circumstances in which such a senior person wandered into a council lunch in his bathers. That sort of thing tends to be burnt upon one's memory.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has opened up this debate. What he is saying is that the Opposition at times introduces some embarrassing issues for him. One may decide, therefore, now he has done so, that we should talk about him for a while. I am sure he has given us the opportunity, by opening up the debate in the way that he has-`That this House censure the Opposition'-and I wanted to give him an opportunity of proof.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor to the fact that if he wishes to raise accusations against another member, he must do so by substantive motion.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take the point of order that the Treasurer's speech was totally comprised of an attack on members on this side of the House and, displaying his legendary demented venom, he made no reference--
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will get to his point of order.
—He did not utter a word of defence of the Prime Minister, Mr Deputy Speaker, so you have no right to rule the honourable member for O'Connor out of order.

—Order! There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I once again draw to the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor the fact that if he wishes to make allegations against a member, he must do so by substantive motion.
—I am not making any allegations that have not previously been made. I just thought that I would read a bit of the Burns report--
—It is irrelevant whether they are previously made ones or not.

—The Burns report to the New South Wales Australian Labor Party-a report by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Tom Burns-into the administration of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party, 1970--
—Oh!
—Once the Government side opens up the debate, we find in there evidence of rorting of votes by the Treasurer. He certainly knew how to count in those days!
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will not cast aspersions on another member except in the form that the Standing Orders allow.
—You allowed the Treasurer to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the Leader of the Opposition to cease interjecting. The honourable member for O'Connor will proceed with the debate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Order!

—It seems that there is a sensitivity amongst Government members about that particular report, and one wonders why, since it was made by their own President at that time and shows some massive discrepancies in votes--
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will proceed to the rest of the debate.

—Well, it does not really matter, does it? Let us get back to our Treasurer. We have a few minutes left. The Prime Minister clearly misled the House. What is more, he has clearly misled the people. The public are entitled to fair treatment on these occasions. He saw that that was not going to be productive. He is not now talking about what Sir Jack said because Betty Diamond has confirmed that in substance. He talks about pressure on the Gold Coast City Council. Of course, the council members are concerned and embarrassed by the remarks of Mr Gibbs, who is a member of their own Party in Queensland. They are concerned and embarrassed about the remarks of the honourable member for Capricornia, Mr Wright. He said in the Queensland Parliament that Kornhauser and Saffron had been linked for more the 30 years. He told the Parliament that Kornhauser also had connections with a Minister in the chamber-whom the Treasurer was just bucketing. He said he had a copy of a confidential South Australian police internal report which linked Saffron and his organisation with drugs, prostitution and the laundering of money, and that the Kornhauser application should not have been considered. He asked the Police Minister and the Deputy Premier to release reports and details of casino investigations. This is a member of Labor's Caucus. No wonder the Prime Minister might feel embarrassed by those connections. The Prime Minister has got caught with his finger in the till. Yesterday he was telling untruths to this Parliament. Today he has had to back down on them. As Pettifer says, he should be held in contempt for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those people who are decent, ordinary Australian citizens who may be listening to this debate or who may be visiting, might be wondering what this debate is all about. First of all, it is about an opposition that has run out of policies, run out of philosophy and run out of ideas, an opposition that has got a leader who rates on the poll at 28 per cent. People who say that they are supporters of the Liberal Party also say that they prefer Bob Hawke as Prime Minister. In that situation, what we have is an exercise in political belittling.
—Who said that?
—Order! The honourable member for Adelaide will cease interjecting.

—What we are seeing in that situation-it is not even a very clever political ploy-is that those opposite use any argument at all, no matter how despicable or lacking in principle, to tear down the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). When members of the Opposition launch this argument, they also invoke a totally new and false and specious doctrine. That doctrine is this: if any citizen in this Commonwealth or his family are grievously libelled and slandered, they have recourse to our courts. The courts will determine on the facts in issue and will determine what award for damages will be given. Is that not a right that has been exercised from time to time by parliamentarians in State and Commonwealth parliaments in order to defend their reputations and the reputations of their families? But now we have a new and novel doctrine advanced by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Presumably if he, his wife or his children were grievously slandered, he would say that to exercise the rights he has by virtue of the rule of law in this country, just because he is a politician if he does that he is involved in some sort of bullying tactic. What nonsense that is. Every parliamentarian has no more or less rights than the average citizen within the law. The Leader of the Opposition has a few more advantages in this place. Unfortunately, many members are prepared to use the processes of this House as a coward's castle to slander Australian citizens who have no recourse and no possibility of answering. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was invited yesterday-this was not an exercise in bullying-if he really believed that the Prime Minister of this nation, one of the most popular Prime Ministers in Australia's history, had his fingers in the till, to go outside the Parliament, call a press conference and say it. But that is not his tactic; that is not the process.
—What about Peter Duncan?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Adelaide.
—What is this motion all about? It is about a woman called Mrs Diamond. I have never met the woman.
—And Jack Egerton.

—Anybody who knows Jack Egerton knows that he has been full of political malevolence directed at the senior leadership of the Labor Party ever since he left. What I am saying to the honourable member for McPherson is this: I do not have any argument with this woman, who happens to be a member of the Liberal Party.
—She is not.
—Is she a member of the National Party?
—I don't know.

—I thought she was advertised in the newspaper-perhaps they have got it wrong-as a former member of the Liberal Party, as a councillor on the Gold Coast Council. That is my recollection. In any event, she says that she remembers a conversation the Prime Minister had many years ago-not when he was a member of this Parliament or Prime Minister of Australia, but when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Other people were present at that function whose recollection is totally different, and they have said that. The Prime Minister denies it.
—What? Eight years later?
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—Let us deal with the honourable member for McPherson. The honourable member got up in the House today-this is the level of his research-and asked a question: Were the Prime Minister and I at the Gazebo Hotel with Russ Hinze and Mr Kornhauser in order to discuss and advance Mr Kornhauser's prospects for a casino licence? One is entitled to presume that before any honourable member asked that question he has some prima facie evidence to show the efficacy of it. I say to the honourable member and to this House: I have never been to the Gazebo Hotel. There might be some hotels I have been in that I have forgotten, but that is not the case in this instance. I have never been in the Gazebo Hotel with Mr Kornhauser; I have never been in the presence of Mr Kornhauser and Mr Hinze; and I have never been in the presence of Mr Hinze, Mr Kornhauser and the Prime Minister at any one time. I have never participated in any discussions with any of those gentlemen in terms of Mr Kornhauser's casino licence. It does not have to be true. I do not know who gave the honourable member for McPherson that kind of political scuttlebutt, but honourable members can see the level to which members of this Opposition have sunk. They do not say, `What is your evidence? Did you take a photograph? Who will come forward and swear to this?' That does not matter. The important thing is to ask the question, get it on notice, and then make somebody deny it.

SPEECH.PARA: This tactic is being used increasingly by this sad and lamentable Opposition. Why? Because it is adopting the political morality of the honourable member for O'Connor. The honourable member for O'Connor really believes his own propaganda; he does not make any secret of it. He has the field marshal's baton in his knapsack. When the knives finally go into John Howard, he wants to be considered as a contender. He has said that. All sorts of people are entitled to their delusions of grandeur, and I do not deny the honourable member for O'Connor his delusions of grandeur. But when he goes to the blue rinse Rotary Club, the blue rinse set in Sydney or Melbourne, and says, `You know, they call me Ironbar because I am so tough, I am so fearless, and all those fellows are frightened of me', he knows why he is called Ironbar and he ought to have the decency and the honesty to tell those blue rinse ladies that the reason he got that nickname was for a not very commendable activity, for a cowardly assault for which he was convicted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have drawn the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor to the fact that he should not attack other members. I draw the Minister's attention to that as well.

—I will let it rest there. I say to the honourable member for O'Connor that he is entitled to his delusions of grandeur, but he should not deceive the poor old ladies. He should not tell them that he is something he is not. Did the honourable member for McPherson ever complain--
—Wait a minute. When are you going to defend your Prime Minister?

—I am happy to defend the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister needs no defence from me. If the honourable member understood the processes of this Parliament he would see that the Prime Minister has denied in this Parliament the accuracy of the allegation made by Councillor Betty Diamond. Think of the enormity of it. This is the basis of the Opposition's case: here is a very influential man and she is on a very conservative council. There is an application for development by Mr Kornhauser, who had been in that area for some time, and everybody knew all about it. The Prime Minister says, `Oh well, you had better give Eddie a go'. My word, that was like God talking to her. She immediately ran off and said, `Oh fellows, this is very impressive'.
—What? Eight years later?

—It is rubbish, and the honourable member knows it is rubbish. Has the honourable member ever condemned the Kornhauser development? Has he ever said that this was not in the interests of the Gold Coast? Of course not. Let us be honest. I have known Mr Kornhauser now for 20 years-I do not make any apology for that-and I have known his family. I knew when he was operating in Melbourne that there was a totally vicious document about Mr Kornhauser circulated by a gentleman called Zion, an undischarged bankrupt. That document went to every political leader in Victoria. The honourable member should write this down. I will give him the information and I will give him a copy of the document.
—One of your fellows read it in the Parliament in Queensland.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor continues to interject. If he interjects again, I shall deal with him.

—The document went to the leaders of the Liberal Party, the National Party-or the Country Party as it was then-in Victoria. Not one party would touch it with a 40-foot pole. But that has been the basis of continuous allegations against Mr Kornhauser. Let us also look at that. What was Mr Kornhauser's sin? Was it association with the Prime Minister? The presumption that members of the Opposition want people to draw is that if a person has a personal relationship with somebody, then it is guilt by association. What did Mr Kornhauser do? He lent a then Minister of the Party of the honourable member for McPherson two large sums of money because it was a personal request. Of all the sordid allegations that have come out of the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activity and Associated Police Misconduct the only person who seems to have got his money back and his interest is Mr Kornhauser. The fact that he happens to know the Prime Minister is grist to the bowl of these particular geese. Let us think about it. The people of Australia have been watching a sordid exercise unravel where members of the National Party have disgraced the body politic in Australia. That is the reality. Has the honourable member for McPherson condemned any of that?
—What about Rex Jackson?
—The honourable member for Farrer will cease interjecting.

—That is not the issue. The issue is that Mr Kornhauser was the friend of a former National Party leader and is also a friend of the Prime Minister. By the way, he is a friend of mine. I do not make any apology for that. It is sad and lamentable that a man can go under an ordeal by slander, which has been repeated in this House today, without any regard for the facts. Because I know the Kornhauser family, let me say this-Mr Kornhauser will tell Opposition members this if they ask him-I have met Mr Kornhauser on many social occasions. I once met Mr Kornhauser and his brother in dinner suits going off to a Liberal Party fundraising rally at the Windsor Hotel in Melbourne. If those opposite ask him, he will tell them that he contributes equally to all three political parties. That man has been dragged in on what is a totally specious and false exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: What is at the heart of this exercise? It is a dispirited Opposition with a political leader that it is trying to mount as an alternative Prime Minister. There are some things which Opposition members can do and there are some things which they cannot do. They have tried to fix John Howard's hair up, they have got him a new set of spectacles, and they have fixed up his teeth. If there were an operation that could be performed to produce in the Leader of the Opposition an ounce of political integrity and courage and an ability to concentrate on the grave issues that face this nation, I would be the first to take the hat around. I have no doubt that Mr Kornhauser, being a generous spirit, would be prepared to donate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know all about his generous spirit, don't you?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time to bring the debate back to what it is all about. Three Government speakers have talked about everything but the issue. I remind the House that the issue is this: yesterday I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not a fact that on 16 April 1980 the Prime Minister attended a luncheon comprising Mr Eddie Kornhauser and members of the Gold Coast City Council health and planning committee? Is it not a fact that Mr Kornhauser's Paradise Centre proposal was discussed during the luncheon? Is it not a fact that the Prime Minister told the members of the committee at that luncheon that the Gold Coast City Council should approve Mr Kornhauser's proposal? Is it not a fact that at one stage the Prime Minister said to the Council members that they should `look after Eddie'?

That is what this debate is all about-whether the Prime Minister was at that luncheon and whether he sought to influence the council. Yesterday in this House he said that he could not answer any of that. He said, `On legal advice, I'm not going to say any more'. Right at the start of my question I said that it had nothing to do with the matters raised by Sir John Egerton. Yet he stood up yesterday, hid behind the legal skirts and said that he could not answer the question. Today he came into this House and said, `Well, the writ was not against Egerton; it was against the Sunday Mail'. We have moved this censure motion because he has misled the House. This matter began with a comment by Sir Jack Egerton that he had telephoned the then mayor, Keith Hunt. I quote from the Sunday Mail:
Former Gold Coast deputy mayor Sir John Egerton said that Mr Hawke had once phoned the Gold Coast mayor-
that is, Keith Hunt-
asking favours for developer Mr Eddie Kornhauser.
Sir John said former Labor mayor Ald Keith Hunt told him Mr Hawke had called to say: ``Give Eddie a go.''

He said, `Look after Eddie', just as he did at that luncheon. That is how it all started. Mrs Betty Diamond was at that meeting I mentioned. I heard that she was there so I rang her and asked what had happened at the meeting. She told me. I said, `Are you prepared to make a statement?' and she said that she was. She said she would make a statement because she took great exception to the pressure that was applied to her and other members of the Gold Coast City Council to get favourable treatment for the Paradise Centre. Both aldermen-Sir Jack Egerton and Betty Diamond-have since left the Council. There is nothing in this for them. They are not standing for election. They are not trying to gain points or publicity. Both have made statements because they felt that it was the right thing to do.

The Prime Minister is accused of seeking to influence a decision in favour of a friend. Yet today he said: `Well, I agree. I was there. Yes, I took part in the discussions and I cannot remember exactly what happened'. But other people can remember and I will tell honourable members why. They can remember because at that same luncheon-probably it was an unrelated issue; I do not know what the issue was-the Prime Minister was in one of his most abusive moods. At that time he was the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Mrs Diamond remembers the lunch very well because it was she who was abused by the then leader of the ACTU. So there is no question about Mrs Diamond's memory. She remembers exactly what happened. The Prime Minister stood up here today and said, `Yes, I was there. Yes, I took part in the discussions, but I cannot remember the rest of it'.

I have known Mrs Betty Diamond for some time. I think that at one stage she was a member of the Liberal Party. She gave up party membership when she became an alderman. I do not think that she has ever rejoined the Party. She has made this statement at my request because she feels that it is very important to get the record right. She has retired from public life. She wants a quiet life. She has quite extensive family responsibilities. She had the guts, when this issue was raised, to make a statement. So let us not have in this House any denigration of Mrs Betty Diamond or her memory or what happened at that lunch. It has been said that there were two other aldermen at that lunch who denied what Mrs Diamond had said. That is not so. The press reports that I have read show that Aldermen O'Connell and Laws-I might add that both were Labor aldermen-do not remember what happened. Aldermen O'Connell and Laws did not actually deny what happened. They said, `It was a long time ago; I can't remember'. In any case, the best case that the Government can put forward is that two Labor aldermen said, `I can't remember, it is a long time ago'. But we have Egerton and Mrs Betty Diamond with a very clear recollection of what happened. Mrs Diamond is a very gutsy lady.

Let us turn to Sir Jack Egerton. There is nothing in it for him. I do not know why he made the statement, but he obviously felt very strongly about it. He is accused of being malevolent and having it in for the Australian Labor Party. But why after all these years would he choose to make that statement? I have not discussed the reason with him, and I do not know it. But he must have felt very strongly about this issue. Jack Egerton was the Deputy Mayor of the Gold Coast. But the strange thing is that the majority of councillors at the time on the Gold Coast City Council were members of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time has come to bring this piece of nonsense from the Opposition to a conclusion and do something useful with it by giving the House the opportunity to express its views on the way in which the Opposition has used the forms of the House to smear members of the House for some time past, including in the proceedings today. There are two issues here: the Opposition's trivial censure motion against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and how it has bowdlerised that once great tradition in this Parliament; and our amendment to that motion, censuring the Opposition for its tactics.

SPEECH.PARA: On the first point, on the Prime Minister's position, it does not require a very detailed defence-certainly not one that can fill 15 minutes in this place, because no member of the Opposition was able to sustain 15 minutes in establishing the case. Each member of the Opposition was obliged to go round and round the garden in order to be able to fill out his 15 minutes. I do not blame honourable members for that. It would be not possible for me to fill 15 minutes in mounting a defence to it. Opposition members attempted this censure motion yesterday because they alleged that the Prime Minister denied lock, stock and barrel the content of what Betty Diamond had to say. If one looks at the two answers the Prime Minister gave, one went to remarks that were attributed in the article to Sir Jack Egerton. The second came specifically from the question of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) as to what Betty Diamond had to say. This was the Prime Minister's response at Question Time:

For reasons which I would have thought were obvious to every member of the House, I repeat the answer I previously gave: I have been advised, for obvious reasons, to make no comments on an issue which is now the subject of litigation.

How the heck could he possibly be misleading the House when he chose not to answer the question? Yet members of the Opposition yesterday, and again today, were prepared to charge into this place, puffed up like so many Queensland cane toads, and present a censure motion on the Prime Minister.

One useful thing has come out of this debate, and it emphasises the point I shall make about the Opposition's smear tactics. We now find the origin of Betty Diamond's statement here. The origin, by his confession, is the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). The honourable member came into this place and said, `Ah, Betty Diamond must have been around then. I will give her a call and I will seek a statement from her'. So we see the genesis of an attempt to smear-not a voluntary statement by somebody coming forward and saying, `I remember something eight years ago that led me to want to say something', but a got-up job by a member of the Liberal Party front bench. We have a got-up job on that in the same way as we have a got-up job on the Gazebo issue, which I shall deal with shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Bearing in mind that this is a motion about misleading the House, the Minister has just misled the House in quoting the Prime Minister's answer to a question. That is not the answer that was given on that.
—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor wishes to make that point, he must do so under the Standing Orders. He will resume his seat.

—Poor little boy. The honourable member for O'Connor is one of the most childish performers in the House. Unfortunately, only the witnesses here, and not the listening audience, could see that pathetic childish performance from him. There is no chance that he will grow up, I am afraid to say. The Prime Minister came into Question Time in the House and dealt in detail with the subject matter that was raised. He did not really need to deal in detail with it because when one looks at it, what has Betty Diamond said? Has she implied anything improper or criminal? No, she has not. The Prime Minister is supposed to be pilloried in this place. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, when there are important policy matters before the House, namely, the national account figures today and numerous other issues, the Prime Minister is being pilloried in this place on a statement which by no stretch of the imagination could be described as implying any activity on his part that was improper. SPEECH.PARA: Here we have this discussion in the House-a discussion which, as Leader of the House, I believe has gone on far too long-on the basis of a furphy. It demonstrates the point of the Government's amendment to the Opposition's motion of censure. That goes to the question of Opposition tactics in this place-the question of the smear. The Opposition, as its frustration has increased, has repeatedly taken opportunities in this place to smear Government members. When analysis has been put on what they have said, it has been evident that it contains no substance. This happened in regard to two items today. One matter that was supposed to be of great portent was from Betty Diamond, and the second related to the accusation made by the man who got that one up by his own confession, an accusation he made that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) was at a meeting. That was denied in detail by the Minister for the Arts and Territories. It is another smear that has fallen flat on its face. The business of this House has been disrupted to discuss this rubbish.

It is not as though this is simply a development of the last couple of days. This has been the Opposition's practice in this place for a substantial period. There have been repeated efforts to smear honourable members on this side of the House. Efforts were made in respect of the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). When the honourable member for O'Connor was heckling me across the table and we were having an interchange-I confess a disorderly one-he said `I've got `em. What about Blewett?' What about him? On that occasion the honourable member for O'Connor came in, puffed up in his usual way, and got up for a faction of the doctors in an effort to trip up the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). What happened? There was a full investigation, inquiries and no substance. That was a typical worthless performance by the honourable member for O'Connor, with no substance and no policy.

The honourable member for O'Connor must do it because he has no other role in this place. Give him a policy responsibility and he must be shifted-there is no question about that. Any policy position that he has been given by the Opposition he has failed in miserably. He has never delivered a policy in six years on the front bench. But he delivers a smear. Unfortunately for the honourable member for O'Connor, most of those smears fall flat. With his failures he imposes great burdens on the less smearing members of the Opposition front bench.

The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) is now in the process of totally scrapping the irrelevancies and trivia that were the Opposition's health policy and is trying to come up with something that is half-way decent and respectable. However, the honourable member for O'Connor spent his time sneering at the Treasurer because of the Treasurer's apparent failure to have attended a university and on the ground that the Treasurer has failed to have an appropriate education. This is a Treasurer who has presided over the economic recovery of this country after the mess left by the Liberals, but the honourable member for O'Connor cannot even devise a health policy. He cannot devise a policy document. One has only to write three or four pages when one is in Opposition. It does not matter if it does not stand up too much, one can just sling anything out, but the honourable member has not even been able to do that. The honourable member for O'Connor is a failure in this place as a policy-maker, he is now a failure in this place as a smearer, but it does not stop him or other members of the Opposition front bench trying.

The honourable member for McPherson took great umbrage at the possibility of some anti-semitic element being involved in the sorts of statements that have been made about Mr Kornhauser and others. On the point of smearing-and Opposition members cannot help themselves-I well remember a question directed at one of our Ministers in relation to which the Leader of the Opposition said that he was not anti-semitic and that nothing anti-semitic was intended. But the question contained the phrase `Jewish businessman'-not `businessman' but `Jewish businessman'. There can be no purpose in doing that other than to make an anti-semitic point. The point about it is that it was not just a question that emerged from the plethora of jumping Opposition backbenchers at Question Time. It was part of organised Question Time. So it was a question approved by the Opposition tactics committee. This is a small but nasty example of the smear tactics of the Opposition. The Opposition therefore deserves censure on this.

I suppose one of the most ludicrous elements of this discussion of trivia as far as Betty Diamond is concerned, with her nothing statements that imply no impropriety, illegality or anything else, is that somewhere down the line it has spun off the difficulties that the National Party and the Liberal Party are experiencing with the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. As the Treasurer said, one of the two crown jewels of the National Party, one of the two States in which it is strong, is jumping on the gibbet in terms of the problems with which it is confronted as a result of the corruption of its government-not talking about whether or not someone attended breakfast, but about wholesale corruption of the police force and politicians.

It might suit the Liberal Party to try and hide behind the view that this is a National Party problem. I have been following the Fitzgerald inquiry as closely as one can from reading the newspapers. Scarcely a single accusation that has been made to this point relates to the period of sole National Party government. Virtually every matter that has been raised so far goes to the time when Queensland was governed by a coalition of the Liberal Party and the National Party. Members of the Liberal party are as culpable as Russ Hinze, Don Lane or anyone else, for the vicious corruption of the Queensland Government. I take it beyond the point of simply saying `ordinary corruption'. I say `vicious corruption', because part of that conduct involved not just using the police or being involved with the police for corrupt purposes but using the police to target Labor Party members of parliament. So it was not just corruption; it was a vicious corruption.

I do not know how honourable members opposite can put forward this insubstantial rubbish when they will have to face that gigantic monster-I think in another context the Treasurer talked about the Monster from the Black Lagoon-which is creeping up from the sloth and slime of the cesspits of the organisations, houses and whatever whose existence has been denied persistently for so many years in Queensland. This monster is crawling up to envelop them and they are slashing out in every direction to evade the consequences.

The Prime Minister has nothing to answer on this censure motion. It is a got-up job by the honourable member for McPherson on his own admission here in this place during this censure debate. Rarely do we get anything as useful as that to speak about in this chamber. As I said, it is a got-up job by the Opposition. On the other hand, the Opposition has a great deal to answer for. It should be censured for what it has done. To provide the House with the opportunity to do so, I move:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Expansion of international terminal complex, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

This proposed work was dealt with expeditiously by the Public Works Committee. It involves the expansion of the international terminal facilities at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport by the Federal Airports Corporation. There is an urgent need for further expansion of the Sydney international terminal to meet the continuing projected growth in passenger numbers and to satisfy demands for aircraft gate positions for the larger aircraft now being developed and trialed. I do not need to elaborate on the requirement for improvement and expansion of the facilities to ensure efficient passenger processing and the amenity and comfort of the travelling public.

The proposal was endorsed by the Public Works Committee. It involves the construction of a new four-level terminal building of some 51,000 square metres to the south of and fully integrated with the existing terminal. This will include facilities necessary for processing originating and terminating passengers and their baggage, together with associated concessions, lounges and office space.

It also involves a new 21,000 square metre, three-level pier to accommodate eight of the new generation B747-400 aircraft. Six of the eight gate positions will be serviced by aero- bridges and the pier will include full facilities for transit and transfer of passengers, plus appropriate concessions and airline VIP lounge space. New aprons and taxiway pavements will be constructed to enable aircraft movement and access to the new pier, alterations to landside roadworks and provision of a new bus parking area. There will be new or upgraded trunk services such as water, power, sewer and drainage and also associated security fencing, signage and landscaping.

The new work will meet current and forecast passenger growth trends until the mid-1990s, thus enabling an easing of existing scheduled control rules. It will provide the ability for rapid expansion, if required. The proposal is additional to upgrading works currently under way for the Federal Airports Corporation and under the project management of the Australian Construction Services within the Department of Administrative Services-work which will extend the capacity of the existing facilities to better cope with passenger loads until this new work is completed in 1992. So, this work complements the work that is already under way.

The proposed development at Sydney Airport is aimed at meeting a shortfall in international facilities in the short to medium term which cannot otherwise be met at Badgerys Creek in the same time frame. The project is to be delivered under a fast track approach to ensure that the project is completed on time and cost. The estimated cost of these works recommended by the Committee is $A214m at April 1988 prices, which includes consultant fees and appropriate contingencies for design and construction. I thank the Committee for its prompt consideration of this proposal and I commend the motion to the House.
