DEBATE.TITLE: UPGRADE OF NAVY LIVING-IN ACCOMMODATION AT HMAS CERBERUS, CRIB POINT, VICTORIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Upgrade of Navy living-in accommodation at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria.

This work involves the upgrading of Navy single living-in accommodation at HMAS Cerberus, which is 70 kilometres south-east of Melbourne. The proposal is part of a staged development of facilities at HMAS Cerberus, which is one of the principal training establishments for the Royal Australian Navy.

The first phase of this redevelopment, which consists of a new seamanship school, a new wharf, a marina and a boat ramp, is currently under construction and will be completed by mid-1989. In September this year the House referred a proposal for the second phase of the redevelopment to the Public Works Committee. This proposal is for the construction of new communications and recruit schools. This current proposal involves the upgrading of existing sailors, living-in accommodation and the construction of a new accommodation block for junior sailors. The objective of the proposals is to provide a standard of living-in accommodation which is as close to the current Services scales and standards accommodation as the existing building envelopes and layouts permit. Much of the existing permanent barracks accommodation at HMAS Cerberus was built during the 1960s, and the standard of accommodation now provided is generally below the current Services scales and standards of accommodation.

This proposal will provide around 760 upgraded single rooms in eight buildings. Modernised ablution facilities will be provided and all living areas will be carpeted and modern built-in furniture will be provided. In fact, generally the upgraded junior sailors rooms will be slightly larger than the current standards require as a result of the conversion of the existing four-man rooms to two individual rooms. It is also proposed to construct a new accommodation block for 120 junior sailors at the start of the project. There will also be refurbishment of the shower, toilets and laundry components of the four recruits accommodation blocks. The estimated cost of this proposal is $15.7m at September 1988 prices.

Subject to parliamentary approval, it is planned to call tenders in late 1989, with the construction being phased over a five-year period. Phasing of the construction will be required to minimise disruption to existing accommodation arrangements and to meet Department of Defence requirements. A similar major upgrading project estimated to cost some $57m is already under way at 16 locations around Australia to upgrade the bulk of the Army's living-in accommodation. I table selected plans of the proposed work and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the referral of the proposed work to the Joint Committee on Public Works. As we have said in this House many times before, the conditions under which our service men and women are expected to live are substandard in many cases. That is one reason why we are seeing so much wastage in the Services, as emphasised by the Cross report a couple of weeks ago. I am pleased to see that part of the new works is the construction of recruit schools. I cannot help but make the observation that one reason why we need more facilities for recruits is that we have to train more people to replace those who are leaving the Services. It has become a vicious circle. That is not the subject of this debate and I do not intend to pursue it, except to make that observation.

SPEECH.PARA: Living-in standards will be improved quite dramatically. It is just not on to expect young men and women to come in and stay in the Services these days in conditions under which their forebears existed, including me some years ago. There are different expectations and standards in the community. The old accommodation where there were four or more men or women-but not at the same time-in one big barrack room is just not acceptable. While it is very expensive to upgrade this accommodation, it is simply something we have to concentrate on if we expect these people to stay in the Services. The cost of this proposal is $15m, and we support it.

One problem we have-I suspect that the Government has this problem as well-in view of the Cooksey report on the Review of Australia's Defence Cooperation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment, which had a broad look at the whole of Australian defence facilities, is just where is the plan and in what direction are we going? Cooksey spent a little time at HMAS Nirimba and HMAS Cerberus, which have complementary training facilities. As far as I know, no decision has yet been made as to whether Nirimba will move to Cerberus, or vice versa. We are spending this money, which we believe is necessary, but it is being spent in a vacuum in the sense that there is no plan for Army facilities. That was the major criticism that Cooksey made of the Government in terms of its handling of defence facilities. In the interim, Cooksey makes a sensible recommendation to relocate Nirimba to Cerberus, and presumably the work that is going on at Cerberus will look after that relocation. Nobody, least of all the Government, has given us any indication of where it is to go.
The Cooksey report has been with the Government I think for in excess of 12 months. We still have no plan. Cooksey stated:
No comprehensive policy has been formulated . . . which recognises the links between Australia's strategic circumstances and defence facilities.

Although it is to the responsibility of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), I ask: how long can we go on in this ad hoc way, spending money here, there and everywhere on our defence facilities, if there is no overall plan to take care of the defence facilities in Australia? The sooner we get that plan the better, although I suspect that it has been so long coming after the production of the Cooksey report that the Government might say that there has to be another investigation before it can come up with a plan. No doubt that is an excuse the Government will use. In summary, we support this proposal, if only to give the service men and women of Australia some decent facilities in which to live.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

On this historic occasion we are about to move the Australian Capital Territory into the process of self-government. The House has before it a report from the Senate detailing amendments which were made to each of the four Bills for the self-government legislative package. The report represents weeks of intensive negotiations between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. If this House accepts the Senate's suggested amendments we will have at last achieved fundamental democratic rights for the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory.

Negotiations on the Bills were held in a climate of positive commitment to the concept of self-government. I would like particularly to record my appreciation of the work put into this legislation by the Opposition shadow spokesperson for the ACT, Senator Hill. On this occasion I should also like to commend the general approach that was taken in this House. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), who had the conduct of the legislation, was prepared to accept and enjoin a process by which it was agreed that as the legislation passed through this House it was preserving the rights of both the Opposition and the Government to continue to negotiate for the purposes of achieving unanimity and accord in terms of the details of this legislation. I am pleased to say that I think all political parties were part of that process. Although there was some disagreement with the Australian Democrats in respect of certain aspects of the legislation, the Bill virtually comes back to this chamber with the agreement of the major political parties.

The amendments to the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988 will specify a timetable for the transfer of certain functions from the Commonwealth, particularly those associated with the administration of the courts. The Magistrates Court will transfer no later than 1 July 1990 and the Supreme Court no later than 1 July 1992. Judicial appointments to the Supreme Court made between 1 July 1990 and the time of transfer will be made only after consultation with the ACT Executive. The amendment in the consequential Bill will debate the provision that gives the Governor-General unfettered power to make ACT ordinances. That power will be limited to functions which are retained by the Commonwealth. The amendments clarify the application of Assembly laws for the Parliament and parliamentary precincts; make any instrument of disallowance of Assembly law a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901; allow the ACT Legislative Assembly to determine the requirement for an oath and affirmation before members may take their seats; allow the Assembly to determine the requirement of the number of meetings of the Assembly for which a member may be absent; clarify the powers and functions of the Head of Administration and establish an ACT Public Service; add `unsound mind' to the list of disqualifications for potential candidates; clarify the operation of certain clauses; and make some minor technical changes. All the amendments have the Government's support and I recommend them to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

The Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988 puts in place an electoral system for the ACT. This Bill in particular has been the subject of considerable negotiations between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The principle feature of the amendments involves an alteration to the d'Hondt electoral system as originally outlined in the Bill. The amendments provide that, where an elector's first preference is expressed for a party candidate who is not successful, or for a party or independent candidate surviving the exclusion process but still not attracting enough votes to receive a seat, his or her vote will be transferred to the party, the party of the candidate or the independent candidate receiving the elector's next available preference. The effect of transferring a vote to a party candidate is to treat that candidate as having received a first preference vote. As a result of this refinement, the proposed amendments provide for a changed vote counting procedure. The amendments also clarify the intention of certain provisions of the Bill and reflects the amendments proposed to the ACT (Self-Government) Bill 1988. The Government has also agreed to a reduction of the fixed term of the Assembly from four years to three years. I recommend that the Committee accept the Senate's report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 November, on the following paper presented by Mr Hawke:
Joint Defence Facilities-Ministerial statement, 22 November 1988
and on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a week ago on the joint defence facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. The Prime Minister has an excellent record in reporting to this House on the nature of those defence facilities between the United States of America and the Australian Government. In June 1984 the Prime Minister outlined to the House the nature of the work carried on at Pine Gap and Nurrungar, but I am pleased to say that in his statement last week the Prime Minister was able to go into more detail. That is welcomed by the community. Last week the Prime Minister explained some important changes to the agreement under which the joint defence facilities operate, and I wish to go into some detail.

SPEECH.PARA: First, we must acknowledge that under this Government the Prime Minister of the day is explaining to the Australian people what happens at Pine Gap and Nurrungar to a very large extent. That is to be contrasted with what happened in the past. It is unfortunate that when these facilities were constructed in the 1960s the government of the day was unable to come clean with members of the public and tell them, if only in broad detail, what happens at those facilities. I quote an interesting paragraph from page 56 of a book on Pine Gap by Dr Desmond Ball, who is considered to be one of the exports on these facilities:

The first clue that the people in Alice Springs had that something extraordinary was going to be built south-west of the town was the construction of a sealed road in the direction of Temple Bar Creek. This was announced in June 1966 as an access road to the Mereenie water bores, which they-
that is, the people of Alice Springs-

had long pressed for but which the Northern Territory Administration had continually refused. But construction did not stop at the bores; to the puzzlement of the locals it kept going to what is now the entrance to the Pine Gap station.

It was not until December 1966 that a public statement was made that the facility was to be constructed at Pine Gap, but in June 1966 the then Liberal Government was approving funds for this mysterious sealed road to be built out of Alice Springs. I would have thought that it would have been in everyone's interests for the government of the day to have been more honest with the people of Australia so that some of the wilder allegations and stories about these facilities would not have taken root.

One of the problems with the facilities in the past was that some governments were not frank with the people of Australia. I admit that there were limitations on how far those governments could go, but at least they had no need to pretend that it was a space research centre. They should have given some broad indication to the people as to what was happening at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. I quote from an article in the Australian by Paul Kelly on 25 November 1988 when he made the following comment in passing:
Joint control is about to become a reality.
The article followed the Prime Minister's statement. Mr Kelly continued:

Past claims by both this Government and previous governments about joint control have been fraudulent. In the '60s and much of the '70s, the US did what it liked. Former prime ministers John Gorton and Billy McMahon said they never knew what Pine Gap did. Gough Whitlam said he was never told the full truth.

It is unfortunate that Australian Prime Ministers could not look after Australia's interests by ensuring that they were fully advised as to what was happening at those defence facilities. If Australia does not ensure that its national interests are looked after, those who are against the bases could rightly claim that they are US bases. It is important to understand that under this Government we have sought to make sure that Australia's interests are looked after and that the facilities are joint facilities and not US bases, as some people have alleged.

I commend the fact that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has provided briefings for members of the Parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, since the equivalent committee in the US Congress already receives such briefings. It would be a matter for regret if the Australian parliamentary equivalents were not receiving similar briefings to those which are being provided to US congressmen. In his statement the Prime Minister made clear that there will be an increase in the number of Australians working at these facilities. In fact he has made it clear that at present only 10 per cent of the personnel working at these facilities are Australian and that the figure is scheduled to rise to 30 per cent over the next two or three years. I quote the following important paragraph from the Prime Minister's statement:

At Pine Gap, a senior Australian defence official will be appointed to a newly created position as deputy chief of the facility. He will advise and support the United States chief of the facility in managing the facility and its activities, and he will share responsibility with him for that work.

I think it is very important that Australian personnel be in the senior two or three positions at the facilities so that they can ensure that Australia's national interests are looked after. I was interested to read a report on the Prime Minister's statement written by Geoff Kitney in the Australian Financial Review headed `Bases now spy for Australia'. The article begins:

Australia has initiated major changes to agreements with the United States on the operations of the Pine Gap and Nurrungar bases to greatly increase the role the bases play in electronic spying in the region for Australia.
The article later continues:

The sophisticated electronic information gathering capabilities of the facilities and the massive cost of constantly upgrading technologies means Australia now has strong operational and financial interests in ensuring the bases have long-term guarantees.
This represents a major change from the early days of operation, which was determined by US defence officials and Central Intelligence Agency operatives entirely for the benefit of the US.
Although they were always claimed to be joint defence facilities, the reality was that Australian staff had no influence over and little knowledge of operations.

The transformation has been under way for some time but was accelerated by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, who saw the potential to turn the base's advanced intelligence gathering capabilities to Australia's advantage.

That is the test which I think we should apply as to whether the bases should continue: is it in Australia's interest for Pine Gap and Nurrungar to continue to function? By having Australians in senior positions, as the Prime Minister has outlined, and ensuring that Australians can determine the nature of a lot of the work that is carried on by the bases, we can seek to make sure that Australia receives the valuable and essential information that we need to determine Australia's position in world affairs.

In addition, we cannot afford to look at Australia's interests alone. We also have to ask whether the presence of the bases helps to continue to keep peace in the world. It is very clear that the bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar allow for proper verification of the agreements which have been negotiated in recent days between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The intermediate-range nuclear force argeement between the US and the Soviet Union means that today, for the first time in the world's history, nuclear weapons are being destroyed. It is not a moment too soon, and we would be very happy if the talks on the reduction of strategic nuclear weapons were successful in the near future. But none of the superpowers are going to agree to the elimination of nuclear weapons if they cannot be sure that the other side is playing by the rules and is not secretly seeking perhaps to maintain its own stockpile of nuclear weapons in an underhand manner. That is why, unfortunately, in the real world, places like Nurrungar and Pine Gap are needed-so that the West can be assured that the Eastern bloc countries are following the rules; so that we know that the Eastern bloc countries are destroying their nuclear weapons.

Those who argue that we should close down Pine Gap and Nurrungar do not tell people that that would mean that the United States would be even less likely to be able to negotiate these agreements which provide for reductions in nuclear weapons. People who honestly in their hearts believe that we have to do all we can to reduce the number of nuclear weapons should be supporting statements such as that made in the House last week by the Prime Minister when he explained that Pine Gap and Nurrungar make a vital contribution to the provision of proper verification procedures on both sides.

I have pleasure in commending the Prime Minister on his statement and for being honest with the Australian people. He is more honest than any Prime Minister has been in the past. I hope that is something that will continue for many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the statement on the joint facilities made a day or so ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The roles of the joint facilities are clearly laid out in that statement. We have been given a more detailed description than we have had in the past, and I think that, in itself, is a good thing.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of criticism of these bases, not the least by members on the Government side of the House. Some Government supporters have been converted along the way and now totally support the bases. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) made the point-I suspect-that most people on the Government side believe that it is now necessary that these bases be maintained. Of course, that was not the view of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) a few years ago, and I will come to that point shortly.

The point I want to make at this stage, which seems to escape entirely those who criticise the joint facilities, is that the facilities are just as important to Australia as they are to the United States. They operate for our benefit. They provide us with information, and they are a very important part of Australia's security. The US is not doing us a favour. These joint facilities are of mutual benefit to both countries.

Claims have come from the other side of the House-not so much recently, but yesterday this sort of thing was said by the Australian Democrats-that the United States is not an ally of Australia. I must say that I find that an extraordinary remark. Perhaps I can take a couple of minutes to go back to the dark days that Australia faced in 1942 when the Americans came to our assistance in large numbers. That relationship has continued since 1942. Australian and United States service men and women fought side by side in Korea. More recently an alliance was forged in respect of Vietnam, and I will return to that in a moment. There has been the closest possible relationship between our two countries.

For some time both sides of this House have agreed that the Australian-United States relationship, through ANZUS, has been the cornerstone of our defence policy. New Zealand, or some New Zealanders, or certainly the New Zealand Government, do not understand that fact. New Zealand has walked away from that old alliance. It seems to think that it can walk away from its responsibilities and still expect all of the benefits that go with being in that alliance. This is fairyland stuff. It is time that we in Australia spoke more strongly to New Zealand and told that country what is happening as far as that alliance is concerned.

I find it a bit strange that several Government supporters who spoke in this debate last night or today should say that the Labor Party is strongly in support of these joint facilities. Not so long ago at least half the Labor Party was trying to close down these facilities. Not the least of those people was the present Prime Minister. During debate on another matter today, concerning a censure against the Prime Minister, he came into this House and talked about his integrity-not about the issues. I am always very suspicious of people who talk about their integrity. One either has integrity or one does not. Let other people judge one's integrity. One's integrity must be pretty suspect if one has to talk about it.

Let us talk about the Prime Minister's integrity, as he has raised the subject. The Prime Minister quite rightly made a statement on the joint facilities. But 10 years ago he was not saying what he says now. The National Times of 13-18 September 1976 carried a full page advertisement which stated:
We, the undersigned, consider that:
Military alliances are a source of international tensions.

They lead to subordination of weaker nations to bigger powers, and often involve the aligned nations in military interventions. Foreign military bases on our soil are detrimental to Australia's safety.
They constitute a threat to other nations, make this continent a potential nuclear target, and could be used by the USA contrary to our wishes . . .
USA-Australian alliance dragged us into the Vietnam war.
And so it goes on and on. The advertisement concluded:
Therefore, we the undersigned, support the campaign for an independent and non-aligned Australia, which stands for: Opposition to military alliances, foreign military bases-

and so on. The advertisement carries probably a couple of hundred names, amongst which are the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), a Labor member of this House, Senator Brown, the Speaker, Joan Child, Senator Cavanagh and Senator Gietzelt. Honourable members might like to guess whose name was last on the list. It was R. J. Hawke. So in 1976 he signed an advertisement which said that the signatories were totally opposed to the joint facilities and foreign bases and that Australians were dragged into the Vietnam war because of the American alliances. He comes in here in 1988, having been converted along the way, and says that the bases are the greatest thing since sliced bread, that they are the cornerstone of our defence policy, and that it is a pity that we had not been stronger and more open in the past in declaring what they were all about.

Today the Prime Minister raised the matter of his integrity. Where does his integrity stand now? He did not say a word about his integrity when he made his statement on the joint facilities. He might have had the grace to say, `Well, I thought at one stage the bases were not in Australia's best interest, but now I am convinced that they are'. So it is not only a matter of integrity; it is a matter of gross hypocrisy. The Prime Minister, of course, is not the only one guilty of this. I am not sure that is the view the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) now holds, but at the 1986 ALP conference he moved a motion to close down Pine Gap. He was not on his own in supporting that motion. The Sydney Morning Herald of 28 November, referring to the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), stated:
A prominent Left-wing Federal MP accused the Prime Minister yesterday of failing to consult the Caucus over the Government's decision to extend leases covering US bases in Australia.
So it is not all sweetness and light on the other side of the House, although I am happy to say that only one or two Labor members seem to be left out on a limb.

I take issue with the statement that the US dragged us into the Vietnam war. Australia made its own decision to go into the Vietnam war based on Australian interests. We were part of the Western alliance and we were totally and still are opposed to communism, as were the other countries that fought in that conflict. There was one other reason for our becoming involved in the Vietnam war: we decided that it was worth the effort to help people, some of whom were already under the communist yoke; half the country was threatened with being put under that yoke.

I fought in that war and, like everyone who fought there, there were times when doubts arose about whether we should have been there and whether our commitment was right. Anyone serving there would have had those doubts. A couple of years ago I went back on a parliamentary delegation and I was allowed to travel with that delegation the length and breadth of that country and Kampuchea and Laos. I went to North Vietnam, which has now been under communist rule since 1954, and I saw what had happened to that country. The people were living under the most grinding poverty that I have ever seen anywhere. They were people entirely without hope because they knew that no matter how hard they worked or what industry they showed or how clever they were, nothing was going to change. Their place in life was fixed under this communist regime. I saw, and they have since admitted, that the communist principles had failed. But they are still people without a future.

I wondered then, when I thought back to the days when I and others had been there during the war, whether we were right. I determined, having gone back to see what it was like for people to live under a communist yoke, that we were right. I take great exception to the statement last night by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) that during the Vietnam war the coalition policy was, `We do not mind 500 young Australians being killed'. What a thing for a member of this House to say-that it was coalition policy that we did not mind 500 Australians being killed. If the honourable member for Isaacs had any sense of decency he would apologise in this House.

The joint facilities are only one aspect of our Western alliance. There are other aspects to how reliable an ally we are. Grave doubt has been cast on that reliability in recent years under this Government. There was an incident in 1983 when the Invincible was seeking repairs in Australia and was turned away. That was a British ship which was turned away from Australian shores and eventually sent to Singapore to get repairs done. Why? Because the Government would not dock that ship. In 1985 there was the fiasco of the MX missile, when we would not give facilities in Australia for Americans to test that missile. The left wing won again. It raised all the old doubts in Britain and in America about whether we were a reliable ally. More recently, this year we had the Edinburgh incident in Sydney-a British ship again which needed repairs and which came all this way for our Bicentenary at the invitation of the Australian Government. It was turned away because the Government-not the trade unions and not the dockyards-would not give the guarantee the British sought that, if that ship was docked, it would be undocked. Then we had the spectacle of the Ark Royal bouncing around in filthy weather in Port Phillip for about three days because the Seamen's Union would not provide the tugs. The Government allowed that visiting British warship to stay there until eventually it turned away in disgust and went elsewhere.

The point I am making is that it is all very well to be strong about joint facilities, and we welcome that, but an alliance is more than that. It is a partnership and a guarantee that one will play one's part in that partnership. Can honourable members imagine what it would be like if we sent ships to the United Kingdom and they were turned away and not serviced? Can honourable members imagine the scream in this country? It is no wonder that both the British and the Americans are reviewing aspects of their relationship with Australia. The Government has taken a sensible view in this matter. The joint facilities are a very important part of securing world peace. We support that, and I presume the Government will continue to support those facilities. The coalition parties are pleased to see the Government come to a sensible decision in this matter. To those who oppose the joint facilities I say, `Look at the real world in which we live'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to take part in this debate on the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the extension of the term for the joint facilities and the new arrangements whereby, if Australia wished at some time in the future to terminate the tenure of those facilities by the United States, it would give three years' notice. It is a particularly pleasant occasion because this step forward, in keeping with the policy of the Australian Labor Party and certainly in the best interests of the Government and the people of Australia, has been taken as one of the closing acts in the career of the present American Ambassador to Australia, the Hon. Bill Lane.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity, and I am sure honourable members on both sides of the House agree, to say that His Excellency Mr Bill Lane has been an outstanding American Ambassador in the way he has communicated the American position on a vast range of subjects to the people of this nation and to the members of this Parliament and also in the way he has worked with great enthusiasm to develop and enhance the already sound relationships between the people of the United States and the people of Australia.

The extension of the tenure for the joint facilities is, of course, part of that relationship which is enshrined in the ANZUS agreement entered into in 1951 between the United States, Australia and New Zealand. The Labor Party has nothing to be apologetic about in relation to the defence relationship with the United States. It was John Curtin early in 1942, not long after Pearl Harbour, who made that appeal to the President and people of the United States for military assistance and for cooperation. He was attacked at that time by the conservatives in this country because patriotism was judged then by the British connection and not by the American connection. He was seen by some members of this House as being unpatriotic.

Time has proved John Curtin right. After the war the Labor Government sought to achieve what was then called a Pacific pact, without success. The United States was wary about entering into commitments, but at the time of the Japanese peace treaty it became opportune and necessary, and the United States showed great leadership at that time, for the United States to enter into treaties with its Pacific partners in the Philippines and in ANZUS. The policy of the Labor Party, unlike the policy of the coalition in earlier days, is that the role of these facilities should be explained to the people of Australia. That has been a step by step role. The Prime Minister made a statement in June 1984 and another one this month. The role of both of these facilities is much better understood in Australia. The Opposition, when in government, tried to develop the mystique of the security arrangements. That caused unnecessary and unwanted fears by many people in Australia about the actual role of these facilities.

The Australian Labor Party has debated these matters on a number of occasions at its national conference because it is concerned about our national integrity and our national sovereignty. The Party has found that these facilities conform with the policy of the Party and are in the best interests of the people of this country. It is our proud role to have made them genuine joint facilities. That started at the time of the Whitlam Government when Mr Barnard went to the United States to negotiate an increasing Australian role. As time has gone by the role that Australia plays in both of these facilities has increased. This statement marks a further step forward, particularly as it applies to Pine Gap. The role that Australia has played in Nurrungar has been very significant for quite a long period.

The statement points out that an Australian is now to be appointed to the newly created position of deputy chief of the Pine Gap facility. We are not there only in an observer role; we are there in a management role, as we are at Nurrungar. That expanded role for Australia in both of these facilities is not only worth while from the point of view of ensuring that we totally participate, that we receive all of the information that those facilities generate and that we are aware of everything that is happening at those facilities but it also enables people from our Defence Department and from our armed forces to obtain invaluable experience that they could not obtain anywhere else.

I would like to focus for a few minutes on some of the advantages of these joint facilities. I think some disquiet still exists in some parts of the Australian community. There is an idea that somehow we are giving the United States an enormous benefit by enabling it to establish these facilities on Australian soil, given the fact that it has admitted that in time of war both of these facilities could be nuclear targets. One should, I suppose fairly enough, ask what Australia gets out of all this. I have mentioned the technology. That technology, particularly at Pine Gap, is such that Australia could never spend the money, develop the expertise or train the people needed to provide a facility of that type. The fact that we are in this joint relationship means that we have access to the latest technology in the world in this area. Quite apart from that fact it is part of an intelligence sharing arrangement. We make our contribution, as part of the Western world, to feeding intelligence into that system. In return we are in a privileged position to receive intelligence from the United States as we receive it from other friendly powers. That is a great advantage to this country. Dr Evatt described us as a middle power but we do not have great resources throughout the world. If we want to keep tabs on what is happening in the Persian Gulf, for example, or other parts of the world where there might be tension or trouble, the fact that we are making a contribution towards the intelligence databank of the Western world puts us in a privileged position to receive from the United States and our other allies data in which we are interested when we do not have the resources to collect intelligence for our own part.

I believe that there has been a quantum change in the views of many people about these facilities. The reason why there has been that change is, I suppose, that a Labor Government has been in office for more than five years. The Labor Party-about which the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) reminded us many people had reservations in earlier days-has looked objectively at these facilities and decided that they are very much in the best interests of Australia. I make the point again that actually explaining the role of these facilities has been a big factor in the quantum change in the community opinion in Australia.

Another factor in this statement is that there is a 10-year term. That is the longest term allowed by the policy of the Australian Labor Party. When that was debated at the national conference it was considered that the term should be of a substantial length because one would not want to see some change of government in the future and some precipitate change in the management of these extremely important facilities. It means that the United States can now plan-and, indeed, we can plan-for the use of these joint facilities over the years ahead. The three-year notice is reasonable and fair. I am aware that there has been some criticism of the three-year notice. Under the previous arrangements the tenancy could be terminated with a year's notice. Quite frankly, if some future Australian government decided to terminate the agreement on Pine Gap, for example, it would take the United States very much longer than a year to replace that facility with one of similar capacity somewhere else in the world.

What do these facilities mean to Australian and what do they mean to the world? I have explained fairly briefly what these facilities mean to Australia. They make a very great contribution in terms of the areas in which I have already dealt-that is, expertise, technology and sharing of information. That defence relationship with the United States is enormously important to us because we have privileged access to equipment from the United States should we be involved in a wartime situation, especially some of those areas of ordnance that we do not keep large stocks of, such as missiles. As a close ally of the United States we in this country are in a privileged position. We know-and we had a lesson of it in recent times in the Falklands war-that the United States keeps its alliance commitments. We saw the United States responding to Britain's request for help in that unfortunate war.

One would be at fault if one did not point out that there are much broader implications than what these facilities mean to Australia. They are important to the world. The arrangements between the United States and the Soviet Union for winding down the nuclear stockpiles have been made possible by the fact that facilities such as the ones that we have in this country enable checks to be kept on the activities of the Soviet Union and other countries. It has been fairly said that if these facilities did not exist, in terms of the agreements that are being put in place to wind down the nuclear stockpiles and make this world safer, such facilities would have to be constructed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Madam Speaker:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill seeks to reduce the number of separate departments serving the Parliament from five to three. It involves amending the Public Service Act 1922 to replace the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department with a new Department of Parliamentary Services. It also seeks to create a new office of Secretary to the Department of Parliamentary Services to administer the new department. The main objectives of the Bill, as outlined, are to establish a less fragmented and more effectively coordinated administration while making the best use of allocated resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The Presiding Officers envisage that the restructuring would result in cost savings-including the saving of 18 staff-and greater efficiency in the provision of services. We understand this is seen as an initial legislative step. Introduction of a separate parliamentary service Bill, separate from the Public Service Act, to establish a new framework attuned to modern needs for the employment of staff to service the Parliament seems to be the ultimate objective. When the Speaker introduced this Bill into the House of Representatives in the provisional Parliament House on 19 May this year, she said:
We are making history as we move from this Parliament House to the new Parliament House. Inevitably, some new arrangements will be necessary.

It is now more than three months since Parliament met for the first time in this building on 22 August 1988. Although we are still settling in to the new parliamentary environment, I am sure all honourable members will agree that the move has created far fewer difficulties than most of us expected. In large measure this is due to the dedication and efficient planning of the parliamentary staff, the staff of the Parliament House Construction Authority, and others who shared those responsibilities. On behalf of the Opposition I extend our thanks to all of these people for what they have done and for the way they are continuing to cope with the problems created by the move from the provisional Parliament House to this magnificent new home of the Australian Parliament.

Whilst the Opposition recognises, as I said at the time this Bill was introduced, that some new administrative arrangements are necessary to cope with the requirements of Parliament in this much larger building, we question whether the best way of dealing with the situation is through legislation. We believe it would be more prudent to vary the administrative arrangements within the framework of existing legislation rather than opt for a formal amalgamation of departments at this stage. This would give senators and members more time to see how administrative arrangements work out. We would then be in a position later to bring in legislation to provide for the most efficient servicing of the Parliament in the new building, if this is thought desirable. Because it would appear that this is not acceptable to the Presiding Officers, the Opposition will oppose and vote against this Bill.

The Opposition appreciates the way the Speaker has handled the Bill. It has been available to members of the House of Representatives for the past six months along with other material that has assisted us to consider the various aspects of the matter. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) could learn a great deal from the Speaker in this regard. Members are still acutely aware that the Leader of the House, by use of the guillotine, forced 28 Bills through this chamber last week in a period of three days. This is a disgraceful abuse of Parliament by the Executive Government. The Opposition has carefully examined the Bill and the other information supplied by the Speaker.

Though the Presiding Officers suggest cost savings will result from the re-organisation, they have offered no detailed report. We believe the scope for achievement of savings seems questionable. It is also likely that the amalgamation will involve increased expenditure by creating another senior position and another layer of senior management over the proposed three departments. Madam Speaker claims indicative savings in the order of $525,000 annually based upon 18 man-years. It appears this is based upon a saving of 18 staff, but no indication is given of how that staff reduction is to be achieved. As the functions of the three departments are quite different, the only staff saving which could apparently be made would be in the area of administrative staff and a claim of a saving of 18 positions from management would appear to be highly optimistic.

The Bill provides for parliamentary relations and parliamentary education to continue to be carried out by the two chamber departments-parliamentary relations by the House of Representatives and education by the Senate. I fail to see the advantage of this. Would it not make more sense for those two functions to be serviced by the new department, rather than handled separately?

Much is made of the establishment of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office. However, that office was established in part as a result of support from, and by way of resolution of, the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. The savings in staff and funds said to result from the establishment of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office would appear to be based on estimates compiled before the office was established, not upon real staff numbers or actual expenditure. Moreover, it is well to bear in mind that the Parliamentary Information Systems Office is responsible for only one function. A saving of 10 staff positions costing some $249,000 is said to result from the amalgamation of the management services area of the three departments. Such a saving could be made only by the abolition of positions other than management services and, given the different functions of the three departments, one can only speculate as to what those positions might be. There seems to be no great merit in the amalgamation of dissimilar and specialised functions which will do little more than create the necessity of a new layer of managers, probably with limited knowledge or skills in their specialised functions.

Of particular concern is the Parliamentary Library. It should have the independence and control of its own funds to provide its services in a responsive and flexible way. If the allocation of funds, staff and the organisation support for the Library is to be determined by a new layer of managers with perhaps little knowledge of the specialised tasks of the Department itself, it is inevitable that the Library services will be provided less responsively. To a lesser extent, the same considerations apply to Hansard.

It would seem that the Joint House Department is finding great difficulty in coping with its existing responsibilities of operating and maintaining the building of the new Parliament and its various systems, not least being that of catering. This Department needs more time to come to grips with its current range of duties before being given a name change and greater responsibilities.

Before I conclude my remarks on this Bill on behalf of the Opposition I wish to reiterate that, although we are opposed to making at this time legislative changes affecting the administration of the parliamentary departments, we are prepared to cooperate with the Speaker and the President of the Senate to bring about administrative changes within the framework of existing legislation which will improve the efficiency of the services provided within Australia's new Parliament House.

Some changes are, of course, necessary; but care must be taken to preserve the integrity of the two chambers, and this can best be achieved by proceeding cautiously. Members of the House of Representatives and of the Senate need more time to assess what changes are necessary before agreeing to legislation of the type that is currently before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other speakers in this debate have indicated, the major purpose of the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill is, in its broadest terms, to reduce from five to three the number of separate parliamentary departments serving this Parliament. The way in which the Bill seeks to do that is by amending the Public Service Act 1922 to replace the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department with a new Department of Parliamentary Services. It also seeks to create a new office of Secretary to the Department of Parliamentary Services to administer the new Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is the result of long-standing discussion and consideration of problems and difficulties which are seen to be confronting the administration of the Parliament, particularly in the new Parliament House. The Presiding Officers, in a paper prepared earlier this year, outlined a number of current problems which they saw as facing the administration of this Parliament. It is worth making that point in this debate. Firstly, there is the difficulty of fragmentation of management and financial and staffing resources over five small and independent departments. Secondly, there appears to be lacking an effective focus for executive coordination of Parliament-wide management issues. Thirdly, there are heightened pressures for public sector economy and efficiency in the ways in which we use staff and financial resources. Fourthly, there is the very important question which has been alluded to by other speakers in this debate about the scale of the building and the property responsibilities and costs associated with running this new Parliament House. Fifthly, there is the development of computer-based and information-based systems which in many ways transcend the old departmental boundaries. Finally, there seem to be too many lines of reporting to the Presiding Officers and there is an inadequate filtering of information that sometimes gets through to those Presiding Officers.

It is in the light of that background that the Presiding Officers have put this Bill before the House. It is a Bill that outlines and addresses those background problems. It aims to coordinate more effectively the administration, particularly of personnel and resource management. It aims to enhance the scope and standards of services to senators and members and to do that in a climate of severe financial restraint. This Bill aims to contain the additional costs which have necessarily resulted from the shift to a much larger and more complex new Parliament House. The Bill also provides for a better balance of managerial, parliamentary, procedural and other specialist viewpoints. It is hoped also that it will provide more flexibility for the Presiding Officers to adapt structures and staffing to meet changing circumstances, particularly in the experience of this new Parliament House environment.

I am disappointed in the opposition which has been expressed tonight to this Bill. Frankly, I do not think it has been opposition of great substance. I think it has fallen into that category of opposition which is simply opposition to protect the established order of things, opposition to change, opposition because the same old attitudes have existed for years and we think they ought to predominate. There are a few points to make about that. The first general point is one that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) made very succinctly. Throughout the national economy, the macro-economy, at the moment and also in the micro-economy governments of all political persuasions are making efforts to provide a better output from limited resources. In other words, they are trying to provide better government, but smaller government. There have been widespread reforms under this Government to efficiency and scrutiny in the Public Service. To my way of thinking, in terms of the general philosophical approach, if governments all around Australia are saying to the public sector and to the private sector, `We expect better performance; we expect you to do more, or at least the same, with fewer resources', it is not unreasonable that the same principles ought to apply in the environment in which we work. I think that reducing the number of departments from five to three and streamlining management and executive processes is likely to-in fact, it will-almost certainly-lead to efficiencies and cost savings; in other words, providing the same services or better services for fewer resources. That is something we should all keep in mind.

One does not want to make this a political debate, and I know that Madam Speaker has tried strenuously to keep this matter out of the political arena, but I find that some of the comments made by Opposition speakers tonight grate a little. The Opposition cannot have it both ways: it cannot wax lyrical about the need for freedoms in the marketplace, efficiencies in the economy or reforms in the Public Service and yet come into this place and resist changes which, in virtually everyone's opinion, will most likely, if not definitely, result in better services for a lower level of expenditure by the Australian taxpayer.

I would not be supporting this Bill if I did not think that the quality of services to this Parliament and to members would be maintained in the future. But, having read the intention of the Bill and the proposed restructure, I do not have any doubt that we will get an enhancement of services and, in the longer term, a lower cost to the taxpayer. The extent of the savings which can be derived from the implementation of this Bill are, as Madam Speaker has said, difficult to quantify but certainly all the estimates suggest that considerable savings in the longer term will be provided. I think that in the current fiscal environment we ought to support legislation which will provide savings to the taxpayer.

I see a number of arguments in favour of this legislation. Firstly, it is my view that the restructure will provide more career opportunities, and more opportunities for development, wider interest, multiskilling and so on for employees in the Parliament. So I think there is an argument there which should appeal to professional associations, unions and so on that over time the opportunities for advancement, multiskilling professional development and so on should improve. There is a second argument too; that is that the rationalisation of the administration of the Parliament has been considered for years. It is not something which has suddenly come out of the woodwork. The proposals embodied in this Bill began more than three years ago in June 1985 under the previous Presiding Officers, Mr Jenkins and the then Senator McClelland. There has been a multitude of papers and discussions on the subject. I think that the Opposition has had more than enough time to consider its position. I am very disappointed that it is expressing the attitude it is tonight.

I am told that the Block Efficiency Scrutiny Unit declined even to consider looking at parliamentary departments because the matter had been canvassed so often in the past that it thought there was no need to duplicate previous effort and that the solutions to problems which had been identified in the past, and which I have outlined, were fairly obvious. The Presiding Officers have been extremely patient and have gone to great lengths to consult widely with all interested parties, particularly party political leaders.

It has to be stressed in this debate that the cost squeeze which confronts all government departments, including parliamentary departments, is very serious. In moving into the new Parliament House we have not only the general problems of fiscal restraint, but also-as my colleague the honourable member for Chifley reminded us-significant problems and cost increases which have been created by the shift. My colleague mentioned a few statistics about the shift from the provisional Parliament House to the new Parliament House. He mentioned that the number of lifts is up from nine to 44; the number of luminaires-which I understand means light globes-is up from 3,500 to 34,000; the number of variable air volume boxes-I am not sure what they are-has increased from nil to 1,900, which is a very big increase; major items of kitchen equipment are up from 47 to 756; and chillers have increased from 600 to 4,400. So those sorts of changes have put remarkable challenges before the administration of this place in terms of meeting the requirements of the Parliament in a new environment which is certainly far larger and far more complex.

I do not think I got an impression of how big and complex this Parliament House was until I was taken on a tour last November before it was officially opened. I was taken down to the basement and looked at the enormity of the sewerage, water, power, tele-lift systems and so on. Basically what has been built into the top of this hill is a city the size of many provincial cities throughout Victoria-such as Castlemaine and Maryborough-with a population of 5,000 and 6,000 people. So the management and running of this complex is, indeed, a daunting task. This Bill proposes more efficient ways of producing the same outcomes with fewer resources and I support it for that reason.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), referred to clause 12 of this Bill and said that because certain positions would be protected in the changeover to the new arrangements there would be no cost savings and incumbents would be protected in terms of salary and conditions. That may be so, but I think the honourable member has missed the point. Those people may be protected at that salary level, but they will not be office holders. Instead of five office holders in the future we will have three office holders and a much more streamlined arrangement for the making of decisions. My colleague the honourable member for Chifley mentioned the dramatic savings which have occurred in the parliamentary information systems area since that was restructured. I have plenty of data with me this evening which I could describe to the House, but I know that there are many speakers on this Bill. I think it is evident to all members that streamlining and restructuring in that Department has led not only to improved services for members but also to significant cost savings by amalgamating previously distinct and unique areas of responsibility, bringing them together, streamlining management processes and getting heads together on things such as purchasing policy and so on, where very large discounts and savings have resulted.

The honourable member for Chifley also mentioned the benefit in the future of single line budget items per function. Throughout every area of government, be it higher education, the Public Service or whatever and throughout the private sector, there has been a shift in recent years to single line budget items because it ensures that the inefficiencies of one department or one section cannot be carried by another. A department or a section which is given a spending item and told that that is its budget has to take measures and responsibilities within its own area of functions to ensure that it meets that budget, that it meets performance objectives and that it gives value for the taxpayer's dollar.

As I have said, I see all these reforms in the specific way in which they have been spelt out by Madam Speaker and Mr President as leading to at least the maintenance if not the enhancement of services to the Parliament, but at a lower cost. All of us must be aware of the wider responsibilities that we have in parliament and in government-that is, these are difficult economic times in the private and public sectors, and we expect new management arrangements to produce new efficiencies, Madam Speaker is putting effect to that in this Bill. She has consulted very widely with all interested parties. I believe that the Bill before the House is a responsible one which ought to be supported.
