We do not necessarily equate efficiencies and the desirability of efficiency with changes. After all, change is what we are looking at. It is all very well to talk of rationalisation and to point out that because we have moved into the new Parliament House we are incurring new costs; but those costs exist anyway. What we are talking about is not that there are new costs and new management problems, but perhaps the best way of managing the problem with those new costs as well as the new management problems. I am not necessarily of the mind that because one creates fewer operating cells one necessarily achieves economies. One does not necessarily reduce expenditure or necessarily arrive at a better management program or system.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bendigo referred to savings in information systems. I think that he attributed some credit to his colleague the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who spoke earlier. Perhaps there will be some savings, but taking the all-up capital cost and the need to keep the information up to the systems-mainly computer-based systems-it would be very hard to say that there are savings. There may be savings to individual members of this Parliament, and that is very important. Given the size of the legislative program with which we must deal in each sitting, we need readily accessible information more than ever before. Going back to the earlier days and my experience in business, I can assure honourable members that I have never come across a computer-based system which has produced savings. We all know the techniques of old, and they are still the same, where the salesman used to come along and say: `If you put this system in, you'll save one staff person'-or if it was an Irish salesman, `You'll save 1 1/2 staff'. But it never worked out that way. In fact, the opposite was true. I am not saying that those circumstances necessarily apply in the field today, but I do treat the matter with a certain amount of respectful scepticism.

Madam Speaker pointed out in introducing the measure that, although not unique-she having already created a precedent-it is something different for one of the Presiding Officers to introduce legislation into the Parliament. Her reasons for doing so are entirely admirable and are supportable by me and, I am sure, Opposition members. They are stated by her to be that, among other things, they demonstrate an independence from executive government. No one more than I would like to see the Parliament become just that and to regather some of the rights and duties that it has, in effect, subcontracted to the executive government. However, I do not think that this measure or any other measure will demonstrate independence. It might, at best, demonstrate that we are some distance in this Parliament from the Executive.

The truth is that the Government has the purse strings. Because of that the Government will always, to some extent-usually to some large extent-control the activities of this Parliament. I simply instance the number of committees we may have and the number of staff we may have to support those committees in the very valuable work that they do in certain areas from time to time, and that is in addition to the standing committees. The golden rule applies: In this case the Government has the gold and it rules. It is as simple as that. Taking the analogy a little further, one could liken executive imperialism as we see it practised in this Parliament and by successive governments with the power exercised by the czars of Russia before 1917. They had the gold and they ruled.

The truth is that the ultimate control of the Parliament's activities rests, to some large measure, with the government of the day. It can exercise that control by either starving the Parliament of funds or, in times when it suits it, providing more funds. Those, including the Presiding Officers of the day, who are charged with the responsibility will succumb. There will not be sufficient distance as a result of these measures. Nevertheless, I welcome the effort and the initiative taken by Madam Speaker.

When we see legislative programs these days pre-empted by ministerial statements of one sort or another, more often than not by press release, which pre-empt not only the party of the government in power but this Parliament, we must treat this measure with some-I hope not of cynicism, although we tend to get that away after a time-reservation. Those techniques are adopted by the present Government just as they were adopted, to a lesser extent, by the previous coalition Government. We saw that presumption by executive government that the Parliament would pass its legislation, along the lines that we saw not so very long ago in this House, where a tax measure was announced in February 1985 and was introduced just one or two weeks ago, and it differed in important respects from the ultimate legislation which we had to consider. That is when we get some measure of this executive imperialism that I am trying to describe tonight.

Madam Speaker mentioned, quite properly, that the independence of the Presiding Officers' positions and their administrative responsibilities met with the approval of the Executive Government. For reasons that I have just advanced, that does not give me much comfort. As to the manner of presentation, it is all the better if it emphasises the differences that we all seek between the Executive Government and the Parliament. However, I do not think that we should take any comfort from the fact that it is approved or not approved by the Executive Government. In fact, I think that Madam Speaker made a virtue out of the fact that she did not think it was appropriate that this legislation be introduced or initiated by a Minister. It might be that the Minister was not prepared to do so. I am not sure whether that gives it a greater imprimatur than the action Madam Speaker took.

The purpose of the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill is stated to be to reduced the number of separate departments serving the Parliament from five to three. That might seem all right at first blush. After all, we have had for a long time-certainly during my time in this Parliament-separate departments of the Senate, the House of Representatives, the Parliamentary Library, the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House. When it is sought to change that fundamentally, as is now proposed, it is appropriate to examine the reasons. I would not accept the admonition of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), who suggested that this proposal is being opposed for other than constructive reasons. The Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department are, in effect, to be amalgamated into a mega-department. Without destroying the tenures of senior people in those three departments, there is to be a supernumerary appointed over the three heads of department and in a line position of responsibility.

The legislation is explained away by the need to restructure the administration of the Parliament. Unfortunately, there is not a great deal of evidence to suggest that it needs to be restructured in the way envisaged and that it needs major restructuring or, to use a term I hate, finetuning in some managerial sense of the organisation. When I see a word such as `restructure', I prefer to use a word that does not have so many connotations. I prefer to talk about reorganising, or even altering, the management structure of Parliament House and its precincts. We do not under any circumstances want this initiative to be confused with the Government's plan to restructure the car or the steel industries, because that has been shown to be a miserable failure and to be fairly seriously wanting. I know that that would not be Madam Speaker's wish, and perhaps it is a wrong word to use.

In her second reading speech Madam Speaker referred to detailed reports which were commissioned `by us'. I presume that she meant the Presiding Officers, because all that information, those reports and their recommendations are not available to me and, so far as I know, are not available to other members of either chamber. Apparently they related, among other things, specifically to information systems, parliamentary relations, public relations and certain staffing and accounting services. The outcome is in the legislation we have before us tonight. When we talk about changes which have occurred and which have coincided with the move from the provisional Parliament House to this very fine and functional building, honourable members may well recognise from their own experience the problems that occurred with catering in the dining room. It was a real mess-up, for want of a better word-and I do not want to start industrial problems in the place, as once happened, by referring to brown dogs or anything like that. But I would point out that that problem simply coincided with the change and the need to get used to these new premises and the equipment that came with them. On the other hand, it would have been very easy to say-and apparently was easy to say before we came up here-that there would be major personnel changes, particularly in the level of management in the catering services. That simply did not work. I am delighted to note that management positions have been restored to the identities that existed down in the old place. I am delighted to record that as a result we see a far better operation in that part of Parliament House.

Madam Speaker has referred to the need for more cohesion, that being one of the major objectives, along with the maintenance and enhancement of the provision of services to senators and members. No one can argue with that. What we question is the way in which it is proposed to go about it. Furthermore, Madam Speaker talked of the containment of additional costs arising from the provision of services in a larger and more complex Parliament House. No one argues that in some ways it is more complex but, on the other hand, it has the benefits that go with modern planning, modern wiring, modern equipment and the fairly new facilities which are still under warranty and maintenance. Therefore, at least in the first year or so of operation, there will be some reduced cost compared to what would need to be spent in subsequent years.

There is an esoteric reference to the need for a better balance of specialist viewpoints. I am not exactly sure what that means. The fifth and final objective is the stated need for more flexibility for Presiding Officers to adapt the structures which will exist if this legislation goes through. As if to justify that, there is talk about blurring of functional boundaries, information technology, contracting of some services and limitation of resource allocation. It is not immediately apparent to me that one needs departmental restructuring to achieve that.

A pure management approach would call for those matters to be addressed within the existing departmental structures, with the preparation of a statement of duties, the establishment of clear lines of communication and the allocation of duties. That is a management problem in itself, but it does not warrant the creation of the structure that is envisaged-the decrease in the number of operating departments from five to three. In fact, there is a very good case for supposing that with the creation of only three departments in an expanded operation there will be even more blurring of those functional boundaries, as they are described, within the new mega-department.

I want to point out-I am running out of time, but I still have a great deal more to say-that big is not necessarily beautiful, nor is big necessarily more efficient. The size of the operation as it is now, and as it is likely to be, does not necessarily warrant, the measures that we are contemplating. Furthermore, I do not think that there is any intrinsic evidence to support that contention. We know that the two independents departments which serve each chamber, the House of Representatives and the Senate, will remain. That bears out my contention that there probably is no need to go along these lines. The Clerks of the Senate and the House of Representatives will retain their independence in respect of finance, personnel and administrative service. I do not argue with that because I support the need for the Clerk of each chamber to be able to service their members in the most efficient way possible, and I want to see the distinction between the chambers maintained. But when one looks at managing the provision of certain common services in the Parliament, as we are supposed to be doing tonight, and when one is proposing a new department which embraces three previous departments-which become virtually a catch-all department which, I suppose, will be dominated by the old Joint House Department-I have very serious reservations. It is not automatic that we will receive full value; there is a real possibility that the opposite will be true. I make the point that, as a pure management problem, if one were approaching this matter one would not do what we have done and take two departmental heads out of a line management of only five reporting to the Presiding Officers. My old tutor, Howdy Koontz, would have laughed me out of court if I had proposed it. As a pure management exercise, that is nonsense. Any chief executive, or chief executives in this case, should be able to handle five departments and department heads reporting to them, with the usual addition of staff functionaries and advisers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the House for too long, but a couple of matters need to be said about this legislation. Firstly, I believe the House should commend the Speaker and the President for bringing forward the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. Most members of this Parliament had taken the view while we were in the temporary Parliament House down the hill that it was not wise to change too many of the administrative arrangements because there was always the expectation, from the 1920s really, that we would move to a new Parliament and that that would be the appropriate place to start to do those things. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), from what I recall of his speech when I was listening in my room, said that we need more time and we need to see how things will work out. My recollection is that when we were in the old House we were told, when people talked about changing some of the parliamentary department arrangements, that the time to do that was when we moved to the new building.

SPEECH.PARA: These proposals are now new. The Speaker and the President circulated them quite some time ago. An amount of discussion has taken place, both at officer level and at party levels and among individual honourable members and senators. It would be wrong for any of us to say that this is just something that has arisen suddenly. It always struck me, when considering the opposition that people had to this proposal by the President and the Speaker, that it was a little bizarre that we had moved into a twenty-first century building but continued to want to stay with nineteenth century administrative arrangements. Often things are said in this House, sometimes for point scoring and sometimes because people genuinely hold a view, and the position of the Westminster Parliament is evoked and what happens in State parliaments is evoked. I think it is time in this Parliament that we actually put aside the blinkers and had a look at what is happening in those other parliaments that we consider ourselves to be like.

I suppose the most relevant parliament for Australia to consider in this regard is the Canadian Parliament-not so much the Westminster Parliament and not so much the New Zealand Parliament, because essentially they are both single house systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Westminster is not.

—If the honourable member for Curtin had listened, he would have heard that I said `essentially'. The Lords has very little of the powers of the Australian Senate, in which the honourable member for Curtin served. The Parliament that probably has the best approximation to us is the Canadian Parliament. The Australian Parliament is not like the Westminster Parliament. Many Australian and overseas political scientists write books about what they calls the `Washminster Mutation' where they talk about how the Australian Parliament is really an amalgam of many of the things that go on in the American Congress and the British House of Commons. Indeed, the Australian Senate draws more of its power and position from the American Congress than it does from the House of Lords in Britain. So we have a lower House that draws its powers essentially from the views of Westminster and a Senate that draws its powers from the views of Washington, but we have trotted out to us in this House the view that we should wait all the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the other parliaments from which we have drawn our inspiration and at the parliament that is most like ours, the parliament next to the Washington Parliament, the Parliament of Canada, which drew many of its inspirations from Westminster. The Canadians have a services commission. They do not have the ridiculous situation of five small departments. In the Congress they have somewhat the same sort of service provision arrangement. Even in New Zealand, which is our smaller cousin, they have a parliamentary commission which draws together all the provisions in their Parliament.

The Presiding Officers have said that they recognise the difference in this Parliament and that they understand that to come up with something as novel as a parliamentary commission, as they have in New Zealand, would not be acceptable to the people who wish to entrench the roles and the constitutional independence of the chamber departments in this Parliament. There are probably some compelling reasons why that might be so. These provisions really put to death the argument that is mounted in some quarters that somehow or other this is an assault on the chamber departments. If honourable members read the Bill, if they read the explanatory memorandum, if they read the Presiding Officers' speeches, and if those of them who were written to in various capacities by the Presiding Officers can recall what was said, they would all know that this Bill contains no provision for any attempt, subtle or otherwise, to denigrate or reduce the authority of the chamber departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one is claiming that.

—The honourable member for Curtin says that no-one is claiming that. I guess the honourable member is deaf in at least one ear if that is what he says, and maybe when he goes to some of his party meetings he will be deaf in both ears.
—Have you been to any of our Party meetings? How would you know?

—I have not been to any of his Party meetings and have no intention of doing so, even if I am invited. But one talks around the corridors to some of his colleagues from the other House, and I am sure that they put the same view in the Party room as they put in the corridors. If the honourable member for Curtin is not listening to that, he is obviously deaf in both ears.

SPEECH.PARA: These are eminently sensible administrative arrangements for which we want to legislate. It is not good enough, as the honourable member for Hume said in his speech, that we should try to do something about this by an administrative arrangement. The honourable member for Hume was a Minister and, as the manager of Opposition Business and the person who aspires to be the Leader of the House, he knows, as do his colleagues, that the three small department secretaries are Executive Council appointments, that they have their positions enshrined in small Acts of this Parliament, and that it would be most improper for the Presiding Officers to slice off their authority and leave the Secretary to the Joint House Department or the Principal Parliamentary Reporter or the Parliamentary Librarian as secretary to a department that had one member, as his Government did when it had the department that a previous Leader of the House ran. It was a department in name only and had nothing to do. We will not get into those sleights of hand. We say that one should look honestly at this situation and recognise that it is probably an absurdity that in this twenty-first century Parliament House we have these five small departments. It is worth while honourable members remembering the size of these departments.

The honourable member for Curtin said that we are trying to create a mega-department. That might sound all right when listening on the radio but the honourable member for Curtin should be aware that the Joint House Department has an appropriation of about $35m and a staff of about 450 people. The Library has an appropriation of about $20m and a staff of about 200 people, and that includes people in the Parliamentary Information Systems Office. The Hansard Department has an appropriation of more than $7m and 156 people. This mega-department that the honourable member for Curtin wants us to shudder about is a department of 800-odd people. He tells us that 800 people make a mega-department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, that isn't big, Leo. You go and explain it to the people out there.

—Eight hundred people is about the size of one of the medium sized councils in my electorate. If the honourable member for Curtin thinks that a medium sized council in New South Wales equates with a mega-department I suggest that he look at a few of the Appropriation Bills that are passed in this House and look at the size of mega-departments. Mega- departments have thousands of people and billions of dollars in appropriations. The Presiding Officers are saying that we should put together a minuscule department that has an appropriation of $7m and 156 people-a really huge administrative arrangement-and which has the head of department enshrined in an Act of Parliament, and the Library, which before it took in the Parliamentary Information Systems Office had just over 100 people. These are not big departments. It is eminently sensible and efficient to put them together. I say to the honourable member for Hume that the sensible way to do that is by legislation. It is patently dishonest to try to do it by a sleight of hand administrative arrangement.
—To do what?

—To put them together. It is probably also illegal when one recalls that the Secretary of the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Librarian and the Principal Parliamentary Reporter are all named in Acts of Parliament as heads of parliamentary departments.
—By all means keep going-but that is not what I said. I don't want you putting words in my mouth.

—If that is not the burden of what I heard the honourable member say I do not want to misrepresent him. But the burden of what I understood the honourable member to be saying when I was listening was that he thought these things should be done by administrative arrangement.
—I will give you an autographed copy of my speech.

—I am saying to the honourable member they they cannot be done by administrative arrangement. We have to face reality. The Public Service is changing; government is changing; the private sector is changing. But there are people in this House who would say, `You can have this bright new building, you can have every sort of electronic system in this building, you can have everything that opens and shuts but you cannot have an efficient administrative system'. I am sorry in a sense that the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) is not in the chair because he has also had the experience, as I have, of administering from time to time the Department of the House of Representatives and, with the President, the three joint parliamentary departments. I found a number of duplications that occurred there to be bizarre, to say the least; to be antiquated, to be unkind. I found it disgraceful that in the 1980s we were still sticking to these tried old formulas.
—That is why you are appointed-to do a manager's job, to sort it out. We do not need legislation.
—I guess that the honourable member for Curtin in his interjection has really got to the nub of the issue. He says that I, the Speaker, and the President are appointed to do the manager's job.
—That's right.

—He says that that is right. I say to the honourable member for Curtin that if he thinks in the 1980s that Ministers, or their equivalent, the Presiding Officers, should actually have to do the hands on management of their departments he is really making an incredible mistake. What Ministers are there for and what the Presiding Officers are there for is to develop policy and to implement policy matters.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable member for Hume-who is having a chuckle at this-can tell me that when he was Minister for Aviation he signed warrants for class 5 clerks, appointments I will eat my hat. He knows he never did and he knows it would have been a ridiculous waste of his time as a Minister if any fool secretary to his department had said, `Minister, I really need to talk to you about whether Janine Bloggs in the typing pool should be promoted and whether an instrument promoting her should be signed by you'. That did not happen and he knows that it would have been ridiculous. His colleague sitting next to him, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), who wants to be the Minister for Health, knows that this is ridiculous as well. But that still happens in these small departments. It is wrong. We ought to be looking at modern administrative arrangements and at amalgamating those five small departments so that we get administrative efficiency and so that we can provide a better service to the Parliament. There is no hidden agenda. It is about saying to the Parliament, `We want you to have the most efficient and best service that can be provided'. We believe that if those services are provided more efficiently savings can be distributed to other facilities provided to members.

I think the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said in his contribution that he was a bit concerned that he never got the right choice of paintings. He felt that if we had this new department somehow or other he would become a bit disconnected from the people who work in the building; that if we amalgamated the Library, the Joint House Department and Hansard he would not have the same services or he would be divorced from those services. I suggest to the people who want to run that argument that they look at the way the Joint House Department has expanded since we came into this building. They will see that that is a patently silly argument to run when there has been such a change in the size of the Department.

To ensure that members will still have an advisory role and an input into the way the previous elements of those departments will function, the President and the Speaker have said that in the new arrangements the Librarian, the Principal Parliamentary Reporter and the Secretary to the new department will have direct access to the Presiding Officers. They have said that the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House will still be the vehicle by which members have their say in the running of this building. They have said that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Library will stay and be the interface between the Librarian, the Library, the members and the Presiding Officers. It is eminently sensible and logical and that is the way it will be. Members will not have other things put in their way. Members will have the savings made ploughed back into providing other services for them. They will be able to say that the parliamentary service is as efficient as what people require of the public sector outside.

In the few moments remaining I will try to enjoin members to see the sense in this legislation. I reiterate that there is absolutely no threat to the chamber departments and that the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives will still remain the most senior advisers to their respective Presiding Officers but that there will be administrative savings. However, there would be administrative savings. If this Bill were passed by the Parliament, there would be a twentieth century administrative arrangement in a building that was built for the twenty-first century. Surely, if we have got out of the small building down the hill, we should be able to expand our minds a little in this new home to take on some new ideas to make the place work better for the benefit of the Parliament and members as a whole. I ask honourable members to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dubois Mr S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. I do not want to take up too much of the time of the House in going over the arguments put so clearly by speakers before me. However, this Bill seems to me an eminently sensible Bill because it intends to bring the administration of this Parliament into the late twentieth century and prepare us for entry into the next century. What might have been appropriate earlier this century may not be the best way of administering this Parliament today.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing sinister in the Bill; it has no hidden agenda. There is no attempt to circumvent the authority, the integrity or the independence of any of the parliamentary departments at all. It is clearly an attempt to improve and streamline the administration of this Parliament. The purpose of the Bill is reduce the number of parliamentary departments from five to three. The Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate will remain intact. The other three departments, the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department will be combined into a new department to deliver to members and senators the same services, if not improved services, but more efficiently and more cost-effectively.

Other sections of our community have had to subject themselves to close scrutiny. They have had to look at the way they have done things. They have had to restructure so that they could provide services to the community more efficiently and most cost-effectively. We have been in this building for only a short time but one thing that has impressed members and senators and visitors to the building is its sheer enormity. What might have been an acceptable administration down at the old House would probably be inappropriate for the administration of this building today. We have had over one million visitors to this building. That indicates how attractive the building is to Australians and how much more complicated it must be to administer. I think that the arrangements contained in this Bill will provide for a more sensible and cost-efficient administration of the Parliament.

The Public Service has been subjected to a close scrutiny. I understand that Block was invited to scrutinise the administration of this Parliament. He had a look at that and came to the conclusion that the reports of previous scrutinies should have been implemented and that there was nothing further he could add to them. He concluded, therefore, that the Parliament should take steps to improve its administration. Parliaments in other countries, for example, New Zealand, the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom, have all realised that changes should be made-that improvements can be made. Those parliaments have implemented those. I think it would be sad and tragic for us if we did not take the opportunity of looking at the way we do things in this Parliament so that we can do them better and more efficiently.

I can tell honourable members that there is some public disquiet in regard to the fact that over $1 billion was spent to construct this magnificent building-a magnificent building it is indeed. However, I think the public expects us to do our job more efficiently, to cut out waste and to spend their tax dollars more effectively. I believe that the proposals in this Bill will do just that. We certainly have an obligation to the Australian people to spend their dollars more wisely than we have in the past. I think one way we can do that is by cutting out what can only be described today as duplication and ineffective administration of departments.

As I said, I do not want to spend too much time going over the arguments put forward by speakers before me. I think that the arguments in support of this Bill are sensible. I think the Bill should be supported. I am pleased to see that the independence and integrity of the two chamber departments, the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate, are protected and preserved, because I think those departments do a good job. However, I think the remaining three departments can be administered more effectively. I think that the proposals contained in this Bill are sensible. I urge honourable members to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will keep my comments on the Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill as brief as possible. I wish to associate myself with the comments of the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois) and the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) in supporting the legislation before the House. The honourable member for St George mentioned the criticism arising from the building of Australia's new Parliament House at a cost of $1 billion. I have to say that every one of my constituents who has had a chance to look through the building has certainly been very impressed with the beauty of the design and the quality of the workmanship of the marble and timber. Those of us who have been associated with the building and its construction understand that that has created a new problem-the cost of maintaining this $1 billion building. Certainly, the people who have to administer the expenditure of the Parliament will be under great pressure from the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer when they seek extra funds to maintain this beautiful building in the condition it is currently in. If there is a way we can cut back on duplication and save some money, some scarce resources, which can be spent either in maintaining the building or providing members and senators with the services they require, I would have thought that that commonsense reform would have been supported by both sides of the House. I am disappointed that the Opposition believes that it cannot, in principle, support the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The last speaker for the Opposition, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), suggested that his opposition was based on the fact that the proposal would establish a mega-department. He said that the proposed new department, the Parliamentary Services Department, would be too big. I was very impressed with the figures cited by Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler, when he explained that if the amalgamation did not go ahead, we would continue to have a separate parliamentary department to look after the excellent standard of Hansard which we are provided with-a department which, I believe, at the moment has a staff of 70 people. I would have great difficulty in arguing that Hansard should continue to be a separate department since it has only 70 staff. I think that the proposal to amalgamate the Parliamentary Reporting Staff with the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department makes a lot of sense. We cannot continue to have three separate departments just because we had three separate departments in 1927 when we moved into the old Parliament House. I think there will also be some positive benefits to those people who work in those departments. I think that there will be a better career structure for those people who work in those departments. I hope the amalgamation will create better promotional opportunities for them. As someone who believes that it is never wise to specialise and become expert in one particular area, I hope that we will be able to develop even better managers and supervisors within those departments through a combined Department of Parliamentary Services.

I have the honour of serving on the committee which has provided advice to the Presiding Officers on information systems. That committee has provided a lot of advice to the Presiding Officers on the computer equipment and other modern information processing equipment installed in this building. I have to say that I was certainly surprised, when I first was appointed to that committee, at how many differences there were between the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate in terms of how their computer systems strategic plans had been designed. It is to be commended that more than a year ago the Presiding Officers decided that there should be one combined office to look after the computer services of the new Parliament House.

One can imagine the mistakes that would have been made if the two departments had headed down different tracks and purchased different types of equipment for different parts of the building. As a direct result, we would have had to spend more money on spare parts and backup and on having expert staff on the different types of software that are available. I think that one of the best decisions made in recent years has been to provide a combined information services system in this Parliament, and in the same way having a combined department looking after Hansard, the Library, the catering, industrial relations and finance and personnel systems has to be a commonsense reform which saves the Government money.

The reason why I find it very difficult to understand the Opposition's stance on this is that day after day it is telling us that our Government spends too much money, that we should be cutting back Government expenditure. The Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife) nods his head and says that we should be cutting back Government spending. Here is a way in which Parliament can save scarce taxpayers' resources. Here is a way in which we can reduce duplication. Yet the Opposition is in here speaking against the legislation. I think that is a great pity.

Finally I emphasise that the separate chamber departments, the House of Representatives and the Senate, continue. That is certainly something which I welcome. So, no one can suggest that our House, the people's House, will suffer in some combined department because of some cutbacks in other areas. I urge all honourable members to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Bill has been a long time in gestation. I believe that it is now timely to move to a fundamental reorganisation of parliamentary administration. I say that because of the move that has taken place to the new Parliament House and all that that move entails and because of the need for all organisations to address their own efficiencies.

SPEECH.PARA: The institution of the Parliament has grown, along with our nation, since 1901. We have seen increases in the number of members and senators, in the number of staff supporting them, in the schedule of legislation, in the institution and development of the committee system, in the increased population that each of us serves in our electorates, in the increased demands made on members of this House and the other place, and in the increased sophistication and complexity of the issues that face members. We have seen also much greater use of the Parliament and a rise in the expectations of the Parliament by the community generally. All of these matters have combined to create the Parliament of today, a Parliament that is much more sophisticated, much more complex and much busier, and on which much greater demands are made compared with the relatively small institution that began with Federation. The Parliament is now, without question, the institution our founding fathers envisaged it would become. It is the central authority of government and, as they envisaged, the place of national decision making.

Having said that, let me say that it is appropriate for all institutions, during their growth, to review their organisation from time to time to see that the organisation is relevant, that it remains appropriate to the times, that it fulfils its charter, and that it is efficient. Let me underline that this Parliament is no exception. It is not a sacred territory within the public purse. It is subject to the same discipline from the people in the community, in how they see their money used, as any other sector of community activities. So, this is important at this time, when the whole of our society, for economic reasons, is being asked by Government and by both sides of the Parliament to look at the way we do things, and society and industry, the trade union movement and individuals are being asked to become more efficient, to become more competitive. Out there in the community, in all of this, everyone expects to retain his or her standard of living.

What we have to ask ourselves in the course of the debate that is taking place here this evening is whether the administrative arrangements that were developed early in the life of the Australian Parliament, well over 80 years ago, are still relevant today, and whether they are capable of satisfying the demands of the institution efficiently. I think the judgment comes down very clearly, particularly in light of the comments of the Speaker and the comments you made yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, that they are not. Clearly, there are efficiencies to be gained from the administration of this building and the functions conducted in it. Hence we have this Bill before us. Clearly, there are improvements that have been made over the years. Each of us can recall the changes and the improvements that have been made from time to time but there has been no attempt in the course of this Parliament to make a change of the magnitude proposed within this legislation. In this process of change it is important to note one significant issue, namely, the need to maintain the constitutional and institutional independence of the House of Representatives and the Senate. I am quite sure that everyone acknowledges that that is paramount. That is clearly reflected in the Bill.

However, while independence is necessary, we must also objectively assess the degree to which administrative arrangements need to be attached to the two chamber departments. It is relevant to go back to the second reading speech of Speaker Child in which she set out the objectives of the Bill. Those objectives are worth repeating. They are, firstly, a less fragmented, more effectively coordinated administration in which personnel and resource management are given greater emphasis, especially in the joint areas. Secondly, the maintenance of services to senators and members, and enhancement of scope and standards where possible in a climate of severe resource restraint. Thirdly, the containment of additional costs arising from the provision of services in the substantially larger and more complex new Parliament House. Fourthly, a better balance of managerial, parliamentary, procedural and other specialist viewpoints. Lastly, more flexibility for Presiding Officers to adapt structures and staffing to meet changing circumstances, for example, experience in the new Parliament House environment, blurring of functional boundaries with developments in information technology, contracting of some services and limitation of resource allocation.

Speaker Child set out, I believe, very clearly in those objectives the type of change and the magnitude of change that need to be achieved. Whilst independence between the two chambers is necessary, we must also objectively assess the degree to which administrative arrangements need to be attached to the two chamber departments. I repeat that paragraph because of the importance of it. This Bill and those objectives I have repeated make a demarcation which will inevitably result in gains in efficiency, particularly on issues of personnel and financial management.

We mentioned briefly the cost of running this Parliament. Honourable members have referred to the capital cost of some $1,000m or thereabouts. In effect, it is a $1,000m investment by the people of Australia in the institution of Parliament. So, it is proper and it is responsible that we should look to the management of that investment in as efficient a way as possible, having regard to the special functions of the two Houses of Parliament.

Let me remind honourable members that the cost of Parliament grew from some $47.9m in 1986-87 to $71.2m in 1987-88. If we turn to page 48 of Budget Paper No. 2, we see that the recurrent and capital costs of the Parliament for the 1988-89 financial year are scheduled at $100.3m. I think it is worth running through, for the record, the composition of that expense provided for in the Budget. The recurrent cost of the Senate is $14.4m. The capital cost of the Senate is $285,000. The Advance to the President of the Senate is $200,000. For the House of Representatives, this chamber, the recurrent cost is $16.382m and the capital cost is $152,600. The Advance to the Speaker of the House of Representatives is $300,000. The cost of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, Hansard, is $7.658m. The cost of the Parliamentary Library is $22.708m. For the Joint House Department, the recurrent cost is $35.224m and the capital cost is $2m. Then there is a joint advance to the President and the Speaker of $1m. In total, recurrent costs amount to $96.372m and capital costs amount to $2.437m. There is an adjustment in that which includes some of the advances I have referred to. The total cost provided to the Budget is $100.310m. It is a very substantial amount of money.

Expenditure of that kind places upon the Presiding Officers, the Clerks of the Senate and the House of Representatives and all those involved in the services associated with those two chambers, a very heavy responsibility to ensure, as good managers as distinct from their parliamentary functions, that that money is used wisely, and that the services are provided efficiently. In the context of that we need to ensure that the demarcation between the two Houses will be kept under review. We need to ensure that we examine any potential efficiencies. This will be the case, particularly as the operation of this new building settles down. Quite clearly, some efficiencies of operation are being achieved as arrangements made in abstract for example operation. But financial discipline requires us to look to every possible means of improving efficiency.

Some of the discussions I heard from the other side of the chamber were quite ludicrous. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was effectively saying that everything is okay; there is no need to change. I will come back to that a little later on. That is not a good enough response to an annual outlay, to a minimum of some $100m by the taxpayers of this country to provide the services to the institution of parliament.

I now move to the changes involved. It is obvious from the sheer size of the building compared with the old that a budgetary increase will be involved. Further, the staffing of the Joint House Department, as the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) mentioned earlier has increased from $298m to $451m since the start of 1986. Within this institution of Parliament, within this operation, there are approximately 14 unions in the Joint House Department covering 14 trades and seven professions. It does not make life any easier for those responsible for carrying out the management processes. The operation of the building is a major administrative task for which the Speaker and the President need the best advice and the best management available. The current system has been assessed as not providing this.
Speaker Child, the successful smooth transition from the old building to this one, is a credit to you-

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—It is a credit to the President and to your respective officers. We have a new standard of accommodation. We have a new standard of service. You have set an excellent example in examining the organisational structure to ensure that it continues with added efficiency. That is the process that each one of us faces in every work place across the nation. Within these buildings we are saying to the rest of Australia, `We all have to try to make do with less; we all have to look at a better way of doing things; we all have to adopt to the process of change'.

SPEECH.PARA: For the management and employees of the parliamentary departments there will be opportunity for improved career structures, for classification changes and for improved working arrangements. The Joint House Department will thereby be in a good position to carry out the award restructuring being addressed elsewhere. When we say to the rest of Australia the words that ring around these walls in this chamber, `You have to learn how to do it better; you have to learn to become more efficient; the nation has to become more competitive', that does not make this building a sacred site, immune from the same pressures for improved efficiency and better use of the taxpayers' dollar which applies to everybody else outside this building.

I want to refer briefly to the comments made by my colleagues opposite. I listened to most of what the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) had to say. I know him reasonably well. He may object to what I am about to say. I felt that the honourable member's heart was not really in it. He delivered his address but, knowing him as I do, I did not feel it was something he felt strongly about. The contribution that was made was really a message of fear of change. Sure, change frightens everybody. There is always a resistance by some people to change. There are always those people in the citadels. Sometimes, I think, within this parliamentary organisation there are citadels in which people see themselves as being there to maintain the tradition regardless of the level of efficiency and regardless of whether they could do better with less money or do better in terms of the efficiency and service they provide to the community at large. In others there is resistance simply to the suggestion of change.

This is a very reasonable, moderate and measured change put forward by the Speaker in this Bill. It is change that can be accommodated which, really in itself is the beginning of a modernisation of parliamentary practice in this place. The purpose of the Bill is simply to modernise the administrative operations of Parliament, to bring it up to date and to reduce the parliamentary departments from five to three. Like the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler, I confess that I chuckled a little when the honourable member for Curtin was labouring on about wanting to reduce five departments to three. Surely, given the small number of people involved and the very large budget involved, we should be looking wherever possible within these arrangements to ensuring that there is no duplication or triplication, that we are operating at the best level of efficiency and that we are using that money for the best possible purpose.

The honourable member for Curtin says the Government has the purse strings. That is true. But it is the Government that is accountable to the people of this country for the use of that $100.3m. It is the Government that goes to the polls and has to explain how it has used the taxpayers' money. Therefore the Government has the responsibility of ensuring that that efficiency is achieved and for ensuring that desirable structural change is embraced. That is what this Bill is about. It is about desirable, reasonable, long needed structural change in the way we do things in this place. The Bill represents a step forward. In my view, it is long overdue. Once commenced, it will produce more efficient services. It will produce better value for taxpayer's dollars. I believe it deserves the support of the Parliament. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. The Bill is one part of the type of legislation that used to be included in a statute law revision amendment Bill and the various Acts which are amended all fall within the general law and justice portfolios. As I have said, the Opposition supports the Bill and it is not necessary to go through it in great detail. However, it is appropriate to make a few remarks on some of the areas covered by the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In the order in which I have taken them, the first Act which is amended is the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. What the Bill does is to allow full time deputy presidents of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to be appointed for fixed terms of up to seven years. The advantage of this proposal is that it will allow flexibility in staffing of the AAT, and it is appropriate that the amendment to the Act should be supported for that reason. The work of the AAT is such that it ebbs and flows. No doubt members of the Tribunal would say that it mostly flows and that, therefore, there is an increasing need for additional appointments to the Tribunal. Nevertheless, we accept the argument from the Government that there is a need to provide for flexibility in appointments to the Tribunal. For that reason, we support the amendment proposed to be made to the Act by this Bill.

The second proposal of significance in the Bill is an amendment to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. The Bill in this regard allows the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, rather than the appropriate Minister, to determine the number of officers in various ranks in the police force. It applies the merit principle to the Federal Police Force and it prohibits discrimination in employment. To the Opposition, they all seem to be desirable attitudes, and for that reason, we support the Bill in this regard also.

Thirdly, there is an amendment to the Customs Act which abrogates the privilege against self-incrimination in an examination by the court or registrar or official trustee pursuant to a court order. To abrogate the principle against self-incrimination is a very significant step and not one which is embarked upon lightly. Nevertheless, upon an examination of the Customs Act, it would appear that there is a need to use this additional power only in extreme cases; namely, those where a narcotics offence has been committed and where an offence has been committed which is subject to very substantial punishment, to particularly large fines and terms of imprisonment. So in those cases what might otherwise seem to be a heavy handed approach is justified. We are bolstered in this support by the fact that the information elicited once the privilege against self-incrimination is abrogated cannot be used in other civil or criminal proceedings. So, for the reason that the abrogation of the privilege against self-incrimination is underpinned by that safeguard we support this amendment to the Customs Act 1901.

There are several amendments to the Family Law Act 1975. Because I wish to make a few additional remarks on that, I will leave them to the end of my speech. There is a rather curious amendment to the Law Officer Act. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be interested in this in view of our present predicament. It grants a deferred pension to a disabled or infirm Solicitor-General who has served seven years but less than 10 years and who is, therefore, not entitled to a judicial pension. I will resist the temptation to say that this might be drawn with someone in mind, but it does seem to be a curious provision, and although the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) devotes himself to a never-ending pursuit of justice and rectification of shortcomings in statutes, this is one that I think, with respect, calls for a little further explanation than the one that we received in the second reading speech. I will be interested to see whether the Attorney-General has anything additional to say other than what he has already said in the second reading speech.

What I regard as an important provision in the Bill is an amendment to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. On examination of the Bill we see that there are amendments proposed which will give protection to third parties whose property interests are affected by foreign forfeiture orders that are registered under the Mutual Assistance Act. That likewise is a desirable proposal and one that we support.

In addition to this, there are some odd provisions found in the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill which have not been mentioned in the second reading speech. I wonder why some of them have been made. No doubt there are reasons for their having been made, but some of them still intrigue me. There is a particular amendment to the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) of 1988 which seeks to amend section 11 of that Act. By omitting from paragraph (a) of section 11 the word `issued', and substituting the word `issued' and then by omitting the word `agency', and substituting the word `agency'. So far as I can see, it is an amendment to the commas rather than anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a lot of those.

—If there are a lot of those, I suppose it is appropriate that they should be hunted down and weeded out relentlessly. I am pleased to see that the Attorney-General is applying himself to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, in this area of my remarks there is an interesting provision which provides an answer to the question which has often puzzled me which is: Where have we arrived at in 1988 after many years of equal employment opportunity and a barrage of laws to enforce it? We find the answer in a provision in this Bill which seeks to amend the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act. It provides:
Where an Act establishes an office of Deputy Chairperson of a body, the Deputy Chairperson may be referred to as Deputy Chairman or Deputy Chairwoman, as the case requires.

So the answer to the question that I posed before-I am pleased to see that the Attorney-General has assented to this-is that we have now gone around in a complete circle and we are saying at long last probably what we always should have been saying.

I mentioned in the course of my remarks that there were some amendments to the Family Law Act of 1975. I believe it will be worth while if we spend a few more minutes on this particular area of the Bill than I have spent on other areas of the Bill. The Family Law Act and the family law system which it supports are a very important area of the law which touches many people in the community. We should, I believe, as legislators be continually astute and attentive to the provisions of this law and to how they are operating. It is therefore pleasing to see that the Government has been giving its attention to the Family Law Act, but it is somewhat disappointing that of all the areas of family law which could be attended to the Government has found only two in substance which justify amendments at this stage.

There is, first of all, a provision in the Bill which gives to the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory the same exclusive jurisdiction as State supreme courts have where there arises under a Northern Territory law a matter which concerns the adoption of children, matrimonial property and ex-nuptial children. So the Northern Territory is put in the same situation as a State so far as the family law jurisdiction is concerned and that is, in my view, desirable. Secondly, there is an important provision to which attention has been drawn, judicially and in other places, which repeals subsection 78 (3) of the Family Law Act. The repeal of that subsection will enable the Family Court of Australia to make orders that bind third parties-for example, a bank-as well as parties to a marriage. That is a situation that arises in property disputes and their settlement. It has been very clear for some time that there was a need to repeal that subsection so that the rights of third parties could be properly recognised.

I have said that the Family Law Act is an important Act; the Family Court is an important court; and the family law system is a very important part of our system of law and justice. It is therefore appropriate that whenever we have an opportunity to do so we should stop and look at the administration of family law and the Family Court to see how they are going and whether we can direct attention to areas of reform which need to be addressed. We were assisted in this regard, I believe, by a paper presented by the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Mr Justice Nicholson, at the Australian Legal Convention on 30 August 1988. For a few minutes I would like to direct the House's attention to some of the matters mentioned by His Honour concerning the Family Court which have not been given proper attention by the Government and which, in our belief, should be given proper attention.

His Honour, in a wide-ranging address, touched first of all upon a number of mistakes which have been made with respect to this court, some of which, regrettably, are continuing. The first point he made in the area of mistakes was:
First, the Court was from its commencement and still is significantly under-resourced.

That, unfortunately, is still true. His Honour was quite correct: the Family Court is underresourced. I believe very firmly that if we want the court to have the standing in the community to which it is entitled and which the importance of this area of the law justifies, we have to come to grips now with this very major problem of the underresourcing of the Family Court. I believe that if we give the Family Court proper powers and status, if we give the judges of that court proper salaries, if we give to the court itself proper, decent and appropriate premises, and if we recognise the court as being part of the mainstream of the system of law and justice in this country, we will have a family court about which we can all say, with conviction, that it really is doing the job that the community wants to see it do. Unfortunately, at the moment we cannot say that the court is properly resourced or that its judges are properly rewarded, and we certainly cannot say that the court is housed in proper and appropriate premises. His Honour made that point in some detail and I urge honourable members to consider his remarks.

His Honour drew attention to the fact that the second mistake, as he put it, was that the court staff are required to become members of the Commonwealth Public Service. The point he draws from this is that, as a result, their substantial allegiance is to the Commonwealth Public Service and not to the court which they are supposed to be serving. He went on to say that it was a disastrous mistake-he used the word `disastrous'-to decide to set up a separate court. He said:

A further mistake and I believe a disastrous one, was the decision to set up a separate court in the form of the Federal Court of Australia, rather than providing for one Federal Superior Court with a divisional structure.

Clearly, his view is that the Family Court would be better as a division of that proposed court. Instead of that, he made the point, which is true, that the Family Court has come to be regarded and is in many respects a poor relation in the judicial structure, and it is not seen as part of the mainstream of the Australian court system. When one looks at its resources, its facilities and the general standing which has been given to the court, one would have to conclude that it is the Cinderella of the court system in Australia. It is time that that came to an end. It is time that it was properly resourced; it is time that it was treated with more respect; and it is time that it was given its proper and rightful place in the mainstream of the court system in this country.

I will not take the time of the House to go into detail of the other mistakes and shortcomings to which His Honour drew attention. Suffice to say that it was a very sustained and substantial critique of exactly where the Family Court is today and where it should be. He dealt with the pressing problem of delays in hearing cases in the court. As we all know-it is not simply a cliche-justice delayed is justice denied. When a custody case in which the status quo has remained for two or three years before the matter comes on for trial, obviously it is unlikely that the court will change the situation from that which is presented to it, even though the justice might be on the other side of the case. A judge faced with a situation that has existed for two or three years will start off from the presumption that it is unwise to change that, thereby, perhaps, not doing justice to the full extent that he or she would if the case came before the judge fresh and comparatively recently after the dissolution of the marriage was granted. That is a significant matter to which His Honour properly drew attention.

There have been improvements. Indeed, it must be put on the record that the reforms in administration which Mr Justice Nicholson has introduced himself have already led to a substantial improvement in the efficiency of the court and a shortening of the delays. Nevertheless, His Honour would be the first to admit that, despite the reforms and the administrative changes that have been introduced, there are still substantial delays which are having the result of justice not being done fully to the parties who appear before the court. His Honour summed up the general situation when he said in the speech to which I have referred, which in a few words encompassed the whole of the current problem:
The failure to appoint judicial registrars-
they have not been appointed as yet-
coupled with the refusal by most of the registrars to exercise their additional powers-
I say as another aside that that is as a result of industrial relations matters-
and the absence of any agreement between the Commonwealth and the States as to the magistrates exercising their additional powers, has left the court-
this is the important part-
precisely where it was before the legislation came into force.

that is to say, before the amending legislation which was before this parliament in comparatively recent times which was supposed to relieve many of the problems facing the Family Court at that stage. I can well remember the Attorney-General, no doubt from the highest motives, telling us in this House not so long ago that the most recent reforms to the Act were those which would bring about a new dawn in the Family Court: we would have a great improvement in the system and new appointments--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time the sun came up.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Casey says, it is time the sun came up. However, as Mr Justice Nicholson has said, the sun has still set, in effect, on the Family Court and we have not seen the new dawn that we were promised from the recent legislation. It is about time that the Government and the whole community-it is not solely the Government's fault-faced up to this vexed question of what must be done to give the Family Court its proper resources, proper powers, proper respect and proper premises. A court simply will not perform to what the community expects from it if it is underresourced, if it sits in inadequate premises, and if we are not able, because of salaries, to appoint the best people to the Family Court. If those sorts of problems are allowed to continue, the Family Court in the future will, unfortunately, be described in the same way that I have been forced, reluctantly, to describe it tonight-that is, as the Cinderella of the Australian court system. We do not want it to be the Cinderella. We want it to be a court which will properly meet the community's needs and expectations.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that it is not easy for the Government to find the resources, but we feel that now we have embarked on having this separate Federal Court dealing with matrimonial and family matters-now that we have committed ourselves on that course-we must acknowledge that a lot more must be done in providing resources and facilities for the Family Court so that it can meet the community's needs in this area of the law. The Opposition holds the view that the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 makes some changes, which are necessary and desirable, to a series of Acts of the Parliament. For that reason, the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to refer to the remarks made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) on the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. He made a very good speech about difficulties in the family law area, but I think that he agrees with the amendments proposed to the Family Law Act. In common with the honourable member, I shall reserve my remarks about family law for a little while in order to deal with one other matter he raised. He was anxious that I should explain the specific provisions relating to the Solicitor-General. It is true that we are making provision here for a pro rata pension for a Solicitor-General in relation to what normally would be a judge's pension.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two issues involved here. At present a person who serves as Solicitor-General is covered under the Judges' Pensions Act for death or incapacity while in office, but when ceasing to hold office does not have that cover. What we are saying here-and this has been put to me pretty strongly-is that a person who takes an appointment for seven years as Solicitor-General is out of the normal stream of practise in that that person is no longer able to take the briefs he would normally take. It is somewhat of a penalty to suggest that that person can just go back to practise. I think that that person would suffer some loss of remuneration. One should bear in mind that judges get the benefit of such a provision and it is deemed that a Solicitor-General would be related to provisions under the Judges' Pensions Act. We are saying that a person who gives seven years' service to the law on behalf of the government and does so at a rather low rate of remuneration--

TALK.START.PARA: —He gets more than we do.

—Yes, but how low can one get? The Solicitor-General has a good case in that sense. The difficulties faced by the Commonwealth Solicitor-General are, I am advised, in contrast to the position of Solicitors-General in the States, whose appointments enable them to serve until they reach judicial retiring age. It may well be that our Solicitor-General will be reappointed, but the question arose whether he should be given some pro rata consideration on the same lines as that given to judges.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman made a very good speech relating to matters under the Family Law Act-not that they are contained in this Bill but he dealt with practical problems. The issues he raised relate to the fact that the court was started in a hurry in 1976. It would have been far better not to have started it. The court was in most unsuitable premises that contained other tenants. In my period in office I have tried to obtain better premises for the court-no mean feat in any city of Australia. The court has been able to obtain substantial new premises in Brisbane and in Newcastle. We have good accommodation coming up in some other parts of Australia, but I have gone to the trouble and expense of acquiring a site in Sydney. It will require at least $45m to build the court and these things take a little time. I acknowledge all the things that have been said.

There is the question of the Court's status and whether it is in the mainstream. The answer is that it is not deemed to be in the mainstream because of what I regard as a mistake in granting it exclusive jurisdiction. Once exclusive jurisdiction was granted in this area, the court was deemed not to be capable of doing anything else in the law. As the honourable gentleman will know, unless one is a bit of an all-rounder in the law, one will not get much credibility. One cannot just be good at maintenance and expect to do very well in that area alone. One is expected to do well in equity and other areas. One might even have a chance to talk to the High Court on matters.

It is very clear that this well-meaning proposition-the use of the word `Family' in the name of the Court-created high expectations that this Court would be able to solve all the problems of the family. It happens to be the divorce court. At that stage, the family is completely fractured and there is very little chance of any reconciliation-nor was there ever under the Matrimonial Causes Act. Certainly, there are those who will now argue furiously about custody matters. Because divorce is now a no-fault issue and the issues decided by the court usually involve questions of custody and property, the parties' anger, heat and revenge are directed to those two issues. It is a very difficult jurisdiction. I have the utmost admiration for those who accept appointment to the Court. There are not so many who are ready and willing to accept appointment to the Court, for the reasons I have already mentioned.

The honourable gentleman opposite knows that we might be able to give the Court additional jurisdiction. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us who are concerned about our environment are well aware of the significant role played by the Keep Australia Beautiful Council (KABC). The Keep Australia Beautiful (KAB) movement was founded in Victoria in 1964. At first it operated under the name State Wide Civic Pride, and was a project of the National Council of Women of Victoria (NCW).

SPEECH.PARA: This project was the result of an empty beer can being thrown at the then President of the Victorian (NCW), Phyllis Frost while she was driving along the Hume Highway. I am reliably informed the can was not thrown deliberately or with any malice. It was the indiscriminate and thoughtless action of a truck driver, who was evidently taking the opportunity afforded by a straight stretch of road and minimum oncoming traffic to do a little housekeeping in the cabin of his semi-trailer. He jettisoned not only the offending can but also a number of other items for which he apparently had no use. The empty can chipped the windscreen of Dame Phyllis's car, but that did not concern her as much as the trail of litter the truck left behind. Because of this incident, her attention was drawn to the amount of litter along the roadside-obviously not only truck drivers regularly used the highways as rubbish repositories-and on her return to Melbourne she enlisted the aid of her NCW colleagues to launch a campaign to encourage Victorians to take more pride in and care of their environment. By 1968, the State Wide Civic Pride campaign had outgrown its original structure. The anti-litter concept was retained, and broadened to include additional environmental and conservation oriented objectives, and a wider support and involvement base was established. The revamped and expanded organisation adopted the name and slogan Keep Australia Beautiful.

Some three years later, the National Keep Australia Beautiful Council was formed. Every State and Territory is now represented on the national committee. The objectives of the Keep Australia Beautiful campaign include fostering a community appreciation of the benefits of an unspoiled environment and clean, well kept, litter-free cities and towns; and encouraging Australians of all ages to participate in safeguarding the character and beauty of our Australian landscape. KAB has always emphasised the important community role and responsibility in regard to litter prevention, believing it is better to inform people about the advantages of cleaning up after themselves rather than leaving the job for others to do. It is also vigorously involved in educating the community to realise that our natural resources must be conserved, and recycled or re-used where these options are economically feasible.

For twenty years now, the Keep Australia Beautiful organisations throughout Australia have maintained a continuous and demonstrably effective campaign, and their efforts have been well rewarded. The effectiveness and high level of community acceptance of the Keep Australia Beautiful message can be seen every day in our streets, along our highways and throughout our naturally beautiful countryside.

In addition to its community-oriented activities, KABC provides advice and assistance on any matters within the scope of its broad objectives to all levels of government and to industry and commerce. It receives funding support from private donors through its various membership schemes, from industries and commercial enterprises, from municipalities and from State and Federal governments.

On 4 December Dame Phyllis Frost, the National President and Victorian Chairman of Keep Australia Beautiful, will be leaving our shores to represent Australia at the celebrations in Washington DC to mark the 35th anniversary of Keep America Beautiful Inc. The activities include a seminar on the increasingly significant topic of the community role in solid waste management and meetings of Clean World International-the international body representing environmental care organisations from 27 different countries. Dame Phyllis will be representing Australia at these meetings, through her role as the Vice-Chairman of Clean World International.

I am confident members on both sides of this House will want to join with me in congratulating the Keep Australia Beautiful Council for the magnificent job it has done and continues to do. I believe we should also take this opportunity to wish Keep America Beautiful Inc. a very happy 35th birthday. For the good of this generation and future generations, I hope that both these organisations, and others like them throughout the world, have many more happy birthdays. It goes without saying, of course, that they will tidy up after the party.
