TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in the house the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) made comments about the recent parliamentary delegation to Africa. I was not here last night so could not respond to the attack made on me as leader. I also find it interesting that at a time when the draft report on the trip is about to be discussed these comments should emerge, and also the threat of a minority report. At no time have I made mention about who paid for Mrs Cobb's trip. I assume the honourable member for Parkes downgraded his first class ticket, but if he, or any member, wants to debate that here or in the media, I am more than happy to do so. By custom and tradition, when a parliamentary delegation leaves Australia, its members leave their day to day party politics behind. This does not mean they cannot ask difficult and searching questions. During the African trip no restrictions were placed on questions or discussion. This has happened on every trip I have been part of and was most certainly the case with the successful delegation of 16 I lead to the People's Republic of China earlier this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The trip for all of us was physically and somewhat emotionally demanding. It is absolute rubbish to say I persecuted Mrs Cobb. We never exchanged a word after our first day in Addis Ababa. The much quoted flare up at the Ethiopian Women's Revolutionary Council came about when Mrs Cobb challenged me to show her an oppressed woman in Australia. I asked her if she had ever seen an Aboriginal or migrant woman and suggested she discuss it with Mrs Harvey or Ms Crawford. My swearing was the comment that smart arse comments do not help the cause. I did not ban Mrs Cobb from attending any function. As leader of the delegation I never knew what function she would or would not decide to attend. The only place I said would be inappropriate for her to visit was the African National Congress College. When the Cobbs protested I called a meeting of the group and put it to a vote. The honourable member for Parkes, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and Senator Baume said she should go. I, as leader, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), our High Commissioner, political adviser and the Secretary said she should not go. Six votes against three, by my reckoning, is a majority. Arrangements were made for Mrs Cobb to come as far as the gates of the College where she would be met by a four-wheel drive vehicle and taken to view the wildlife. Senator Baume conveyed this to her and agreed to the suggestion. She refused. Then arrangements were made for her to go swimming and visit the beaches around Dar-es-Salaam. Again she refused.

In Ethiopia I did address the Ethiopians as `comrade', as I checked with our Ambassador on the correct form of address. I never referred to the honourable member for Parkes or the honourable member for Franklin as comrade, as I do not regard them as comrades. In Tanzania the form of address was `gward', which I used. In introducing the delegation I made the point that three of us were from the governing party, the Australian Labor Party, which was aligned with the socialist side of politics; that the honourable member for Franklin and Senator Baume were from the Liberal Party of Australia, which was aligned with the conservative side of politics; and that the honourable member for Parkes; also from the conservative side, represented in the main, rural interests. This I did throughout the trip to Africa. This was done by way of explanation to our hosts.

The Mozambique part of our trip was perhaps the most sensitive of all. Every delegation member had approved the final press release which I read at Maputo airport in front of every delegation member, with the honourable member for Franklin sitting beside me. I invited questions from the media and when these were over I closed the press conference. A short time later I noticed the honourable member for Franklin giving a separate press interview. I went over to him and told him that all comment should be made in front of all members of the delegation. I stress here that the issues we were discussing in Mozambique were extremely sensitive and it was very important that we should speak with one voice on them.

The comments made by the honourable member for Parkes on my leadership are not shared by our hosts or, I believe, our diplomatic representatives abroad. Despite some personality clashes, I believe that it was a most successful trip. I stress the fact that parliamentary delegations are not holiday trips to exotic parts of the world, but serious and sensitive exercises on behalf of the Parliament. Perhaps greater care should be exercised in selecting the membership of these delegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Castle Bacon decision is now a part of Australian industrial folklore. The decision is perhaps one of more significant recent events in industrial relations, yet oddly enough it has gone largely unnoticed-at least compared with the Mudginberri or Dollar Sweets scenarios. The Castle Bacon story is the story of a medium-sized, small ham and bacon manufacturer in the country town of Castlemaine, 120 kilometres from Melbourne. More importantly, it is a story about how a comparatively small business operator chose to offer his employees what he considered a reasonable deal only to come face to face with a union-the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU)-intent upon conflict to the detriment of not only its members, but the industry as a whole. The AMIEU, well-known for its `thick-headedness' at the Mudginberri abattoir-to quote the Australian Financial Review of 13 October 1988-opposed the deal despite the fact that 460 out of 520 employees supported the proposed changes as more than fair and reasonable. Unable to enter into genuine negotiations with the union, which refused to agree to any significant productivity improvements in exchange for the 4 per cent second tier wage increase, the company decided to deal directly with its employees.

SPEECH.PARA: The deal included: a 4 per cent restructuring and efficiency pay rise in exchange for productivity gains of at least 4 per cent, thereby enabling maximisation of potential for both management and employees; the combined alteration of shifts to enable more continuous production and therefore more effective economies of scale, increased production and the increased possibility of flow on benefits to employees; a juggling of Show Day and Melbourne Cup Day holidays by mutual arrangement for the benefit of both parties; and the shortening of tea breaks by five minutes allowing maximum time on the job. It also included a promise that new shifts would not leave any workers currently on penalty payments out of pocket. As far as management and workers were concerned, these were matters that directly affected the future viability of their work place and the jobs of more than 500 people in the township of Castlemaine.

However, the union thought otherwise and attempted to gain the upper hand in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on the grounds that a second tier agreement could only be made by an employer with a union and not directly with its employees. This contrasted directly with what management and the employees wanted to achieve. Both parties felt they had more to gain by ridding themselves of the reactionary element in the union hierarchy which appeared intent on conflict for conflict's sake.

It is a measure of some concern that the initial reaction of the Commission was to back the union in its push to retain a stranglehold on this, Castlemaine's largest factory, despite the overwhelming desire of 90 per cent of its employees to come to their own arrangements with management. Effectively, it ignored the agreements between employer and employee and granted the workers their 4 per cent pay rise in exchange for minor trade-offs inoffensive to the union.

The company subsequently appealed to the Full Bench, which allowed the appeal, there being matters of such importance involved. These were: the relationship of an employer with its employees; the role of unions in negotiations between those parties; and questions concerning the position of a union in proceedings affecting an award to which it is a principal party. The Full Bench re-examined the evidence and upheld the appeal, quashing the original finding and varying the award at Castle Bacon along identical lines to those of the agreements between employer and employee. The good sense of the Full Bench in upholding the appeal must be applauded. It should be noted, however, that the Full Bench did not in fact formally recognise the agreement reached by Castle Bacon and its employees. Instead it varied the existing award by arbitration, using the original agreement as evidence of the employees wishes. Nevertheless, the agreement was a classic case of direct dealing between employees and their employer with the aim of raising wages and productivity simultaneously.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what agreement was reached at the April 1988 meeting of the Group of Ten major industrial countries about reviewing the role of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in the debt crisis.
(2) Have Australia's views on this issue been presented to participants in this review; if so, what views have been presented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The communique of the meeting of the Group of Ten (G-10) major industrial countries (the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, France, Italy, Canada, the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden) held on 14 April 1988 included the following paragraph:

`The Ministers and Governors exchanged views on the future work of the Group of Ten and asked their Deputies to undertake a review of the role of the IMF and the World Bank in the context of the debt strategy.'
The communique of the Group's last meeting, on 25 September 1988, includes the following reference:

Ministers and Governors were informed of progress made in work carried out by their Deputies on the role of the IMF and the World Bank in the context of the debt strategy. They instructed their Deputies to present a final report in time for their meeting next spring.
(2) Yes, but through the IMF and World Bank Executive Boards and meetings of Fund and Bank governors, not direct to the G-10.

The role of the IMF and World Bank in the debt strategy is a subject of continuing discussion in the Executive Boards of the Fund and Bank. Australia's views on the issue have been put by our representatives in the Executive Boards, on which the G-10 countries are also represented, and in my own interventions in meetings of the Interim and Development Committees-most recently in Berlin in September this year. While the detailed proceedings of these meetings are confidential, I can indicate that Australia has supported the important catalytic role of the IMF and World Bank in the present case-by-case, growth-oriented debt strategy. The IMF and World Bank do not have the resources, nor is it their role, to replace private financing or to accept the transfer of risk from private lenders.

I also noted in my statement on 29 September 1988 to the Plenary Sessions of the IMF/World Bank Annual Meetings in Berlin, that the Fund and Bank have critical roles to play in addressing the debt and other problems of developing countries. I noted too that Australia does not believe that the Bank should be lending to any country for long-term structural purposes in the absence of a suitable framework of macroeconomic policies for that country. We would not wish to see a situation develop in which borrowing countries were able to exploit a duplication of IMF and World Bank roles and play one institution off against the other to obtain balance of payments financing from one institution that the other was not willing to provide.
The role of the IMF and World Bank in the debt strategy can be described briefly as follows:

The IMF's role in the debt strategy is essentially to assist member countries to design effective growth-oriented adjustment programs, monitor their implementation, provide its own financial support to smooth the adjustment process, and mobilise finance from other sources. Private lenders have often predicated their own lending on the existence of an IMF-supported adjustment program, which is taken as evidence that a debtor country is tackling seriously its economic difficulties.

The World Bank's longer-term structural adjustment lending fulfils a similar catalytic function, supplemented in appropriate cases by credit enhancement measures through the Bank's commercial cofinancing program. The Bank's traditional project lending also contributes importantly to ameliorating debt problems by increasing the productive capacity and growth potential of borrowing countries.

The IMF and World Bank also provide technical assistance aimed at strengthening the debt management capacity of developing member countries. In addition, they undertake technical work on voluntary, market-based `menu' options designed to reduce debt and increase private financial flows without transferring risk from private lenders to official creditors and taxpayers.

The wider role of the two organisations-and of the IMF in particular-in helping to strengthen international policy coordination, reduce global imbalances and improve the functioning of the international monetary and trading system is aimed at producing a world economic climate in which debt problems can be more satisfactorily resolved.
